urn:contentItem:5XWX-X6F1-JBF5-T4KG-00000-00Fires in East Gippsland prompt helicopter evacuation as Victoria's north-east hit hard2020-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:43ZLexisNexisFires in East Gippsland prompt helicopter evacuation as Victoria's north-east hit hard

Army helicopters have been used to help dozens of people escape the fierce fire threat in Victoria, where more than 100 properties have been razed and towns remain at risk tonight.

Strong winds are continuing to push fires towards communities in Victoria's north-east and East Gippsland, where six people remain missing.

Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp said at least 110 properties and 220 outbuildings had been lost - but the full scale of the damage is not yet known after thousands of people fled threatened communities.

"There's still many, many communities that we've not been able to really get into and do a proper assessment," he said.

Premier Daniel Andrews said the number of people missing had been revised down from 21 to six, but the state was by "no means out of this".

"Our biggest concern at the moment is very significant fire activity in the north-east of the state," Premier Daniel Andrews said this evening.

"We have about 1,000 firefighters on the fire ground."

In the East Gippsland town of Omeo, residents have described seeing the sky turn red, and then black, as a fire front hit.

Around 50 people were evacuated using Army helicopters as residents huddled on a sports oval.

Local Brian Hadden said it had been "a hell of a day".

"I can see lots of wind and hell of a lot of smoke," he told ABC Gippsland this afternoon.

"Where I am at the Omeo Recreation Reserve, there is about six or seven big choppers, army and police."

Alpine and border towns face overnight threat

Just to the west, bushfires are threatening Alpine communities at Dinner Plain, Mount Hotham, Falls Creek and Bright, with hot temperatures persisting into the night.

Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp said there was a risk fires that had threatened Harrietville and Wandiligong could flare and impact the popular tourist town of Bright as well.

"So we are doing what we can, but keeping a very close eye on that particular fire and the potential impact into those valleys," he said.

Close to the border, Commissioner Crisp said the destructive blaze that hit the outskirts of Corryong earlier in the week was being pushed back towards the town, as well as Tintaldra and Towong.

He said property losses in those towns were likely as the Victorian blaze came together with another fire burning parallel to it over the NSW border.

Many residents from that region evacuated to Tallangatta, Wangaratta and Wodonga on Friday.

On Saturday, Australian Defence Force members ran further evacuations from Tallangatta to take people further back from the fire zone.

Authorities said forecast "firestorm conditions which may not be survivable" were playing out, with a "significant" increase in fire activity.

Cooler temperatures which swept East Gippsland are taking longer to reach the north-east, with Albury still sitting at 41C at 6:00pm.

The Murray Valley Highway has been closed because of the risk of it being hit by fire.

Euroa bushfire threatens Hume Freeway

Firefighters were further stretched in the afternoon when a new blaze broke out near Euroa, south-west of Wangaratta, and began to head towards the Hume Freeway.

A large air tanker dropped fire retardant on the Euroa service centre in the path of the blaze and some freeway lanes were closed.

About 50 trucks and aircraft were sent to Euroa and the spread of the fire was slowed, but authorities warned that could change at any time overnight.

The freeway is one of Victoria's biggest roads, linking Melbourne to the north-east of the state and on to Sydney.

Southbound lanes of the freeway at Euroa will remain closed overnight, with traffic detoured through the town before a hazard assessment can be done on Sunday.

Omeo residents shelter together, Cann River cut off

Before the helicopter evacuations from Omeo began, Sandy Beltrame from the Omeo Caravan Park said about 150 people were sheltering at the local recreation reserve as she and other residents prepared to defend their homes.

"How am I feeling at the moment? I've got my big girl pants on, and my big girl shirt over the top of it and a broad brim hat and lots of hoses ready to go," she said.

Authorities had been warning communities across Victoria's declared disaster zone to evacuate the area before today, amid fears the extreme weather would make bushfires unstoppable.

This afternoon, five evacuation notices and more than a dozen emergency warnings were in place in the state's east and north-east.

Mr Gillham said residents at Cann River, who were urged to evacuate this week, were "essentially isolated" now as fire moved towards them from the east.

"We have been in there with the Australian Defence Force aircraft and we have also conveyed people out of Cann River but it is essentially an isolated community, the road is completely blocked by fallen trees," he told ABC Gippsland.

Ember attack at Club Terrace

Club Terrace is another community where residents have been cut off by trees on roads.

This afternoon, ABC Radio Melbourne caller Graham said the sky had turned red there, and he and other residents were waiting to fight fires as the area came under ember attack.

"It's been completely blacked out and red again. But all we can see near us is a few flare-ups," he said.

About 50 firefighters from the United States are preparing to join the battle against the East Gippsland bushfires, which authorities estimate have torn through more than 700,000 hectares of land.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's deputy chief fire officer Beth Roberts said authorities were working to juggle both firefighting and relief as they responded to the "unprecedented" bushfire emergency across East Gippsland.

"While we are absolutely concentrating on response, it is important for us to be looking at immediate relief and recovery," she said.

Late this afternoon, cooler temperatures reached East Gippsland. It dropped to 17 degrees Celsius at Mount Nowa Nowa and 20C at Orbost, a dramatic drop from 40C earlier in the day.

'Lots of embers falling out of the sky' in Mallacoota

Days after Mallacoota was cut off by bushfires, prompting the evacuation of more than 900 people by sea, the sky has turned black once again.

The town was devastated by fire on New Year's Eve. Mallacoota resident Sean Rainey said gusty winds were now pushing a fire, burning on the other side of the lake, to the south.

"I guess a whole lot of smoke has gone up and covered the sky," he said.

"It took about 15 minutes to go from pretty much deep yellow to blood red and pretty much black.

"You know there's lots of embers falling out of the sky, but they're pretty much burnt up and, yeah, we're told ... it is pretty safe."

Amy Houghton, who is waiting to be evacuated from Mallacoota along with her two-year-old son and her 92-year-old grandmother, said air evacuations planned for Saturday afternoon had been cancelled due to the smoke.

Erin Lehman, who is also waiting to be evacuated along with her three children, said the situation was still "a bit scary" as the sky moved from darkness to orange and back to darkness.

"The smoke's horrendous and that's my concern with my kids," she said.

"What's going to be the long term effects on their health being exposed to all this smoke for extended periods of time.

"It's quite difficult trying to keep a mask on a four-year-old and a two-year-old."

Meanwhile, authorities said a relief centre at Sale, west of the fires, was beginning to overflow and encouraged those who could to drive further west to the Latrobe Valley town of Morwell.

Fuel won't arrive in time to keep power on in Mallacoota, Omeo

Several bushfire-affected communities have already lost power and phone connections and authorities have warned generators in Mallacoota and Omeo are running out of power.

Ausnet said fuel they had hoped would reach the East Gippsland towns had not arrived, and it was estimated the generators had between 12 and 36 hours of power left.

"Obviously charge your communication devices, charge your backup power packs and anything you need to do to stay healthy and well," Ausnet's Steve Brown told ABC Gippsland.

"The ADF [Australian Defence Force] has got a lot on their plate at the moment, so we probably aren't going to get those fuel deliveries in time to keep the generators going unfortunately. "

Meanwhile, Telstra said of roughly 25 mobile tower sites hit by bushfires across eastern Victoria, about 15 had been restored.

Technicians had been unable to get to Cudgewa and Bonang so had been working with emergency services to deliver satellite phones to those places.

The Alpine community of Dartmouth was told it would lose power from 7:00pm and the town was experiencing power surges during the afternoon.

urn:contentItem:5XY1-24X1-F0J6-J4H2-00000-00LETTERS2020-01-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:43ZLexisNexisOPINIONLettersPg. 18LETTERSMCook

Protecting our oil

Scott Morrison, I hope you have stitched up that crude oil supply arrangement with Donald Trump. Things are looking a bit dicey with our suppliers in the Middle East but I am sure you are "on to it".

Jonathan Emes, Ballarat

Yarra Valley has changed

Thank you for the editorial - "Make safer country roads a priority" (The Age, 9/1). I am concerned about the safety on the Maroondah Highway between Coldstream and Healesville.

As many wineries now populate this road and the surrounding areas, driving at 100km/h for locals - while tourists are looking for their destinations - is no longer viable and accidents are occurring. Heavy farming machinery needs road access as well. If the speed limit were lowered to 80km/h, drivers would have time to adjust to the conditions. Now, at 100km/h, there is no time at all.

Lynne Donchi, Coldstream

Congested fire exits

The aerial photo of a housing estate (Letter, 8/1) is an excellent example of the lack of two exits to an estate of nearly 100 households causing potential trapping of residents in the event of a bushfire.

In my fringe town of Kilmore, since Black Saturday, many new housing developments with courts and only one exit for emergencies have been approved. There has also been no access improvement for similar older estates. Neither state nor local governments have provided funding for escape routes from these areas. How long will it be before such estates on the fringe of Melbourne are impacted by severe bushfires and residents are unable to leave safely?

Anne Rose, Kilmore

Protesting for our future

Ellen Mcgregor says climate activists who plan to protest on Friday "lack understanding and consideration for the emergency services and the people who have been traumatised by the bushfires" (Letters, 9/1). The same could be said for anyone participating in any community activity which requires police attendance. Anyone for cricket? Or how about some alcohol and fireworks on New Year's Eve?

These protests are part of a nationwide action and cannot simply be shuffled to a time that better suits those in the government who would like to close down discussion on global warming. We will be protesting on behalf of bushfire victims, farms and forests dying from drought, emergency workers who are being asked to save a country from its own folly - on behalf of all of our wildlife, rivers, oceans and wetlands. In these times of climate peril, a quiet Australian is a dead Australian.Jenny Zimmerman,

Woodend

Don't do as I do. . .

Scott Morrison tells us that places like a scorched Kangaroo Island are still great holiday spots and encourages us to go there to support the local economies (The Age, 9/1). Is this why he chose to go to Hawaii for his holiday?

Eric Butcher, Eltham

We know all the answers

Is the proposed royal commission into the bushfires an expensive way of appearing to do something? Scott Morrison refused to meet with 23 former fire and emergency leaders and ignored specialist advice. The answers are already available. The millions of dollars can be better spent

John Young, North Fitzroy

The PM's unenviable job

All who criticise Scott Morrison should reflect on how they would cope with not only dealing with the bushfire crisis, but being on top of what is happening with Iran plus demands of countless lobby groups and all that his ministers refer to him. He is never out of contact and is available 24/7. And then there is the relentless media seeking to trip him up and never complimenting him on what he is actually achieving. Few could handle it.

John Weymouth,

Ringwood East

High cost of our lifestyles

Ken Barnes (Letters, 8/1) hits the nail on the head. We are all responsible for this tragedy. We continue to live our profligate lifestyles, build massive homes, drive huge cars, eat prodigious amounts of red meat and use disposable items as though there were no alternative. All these excesses contribute to the destruction of our planet but we make little or no effort to change.

We got what we deserve but sadly, our most vulnerable people and our beloved native animals and birds are the ones who suffer.

Judy Addison, Barwon Heads

The government's duty

Barbara Kingston (Letters, 8/1) raises some valid points regarding our consumption of "things". However, to absolve our politicians (especially the federal government which is responsible for our climate policy) from the need to take action is ridiculous.

There are many ways in which they could drive policy to reduce our greenhouse emissions and, by doing so now, as global leaders could actually help the budget surplus in the not so distant future.

Chrissie Schubert, Windsor

Red tape protects us

When I see the headline "Recovery boss vows to slash red tape" (The Age, 8/1), I immediately see the door open to shonky operators. Think deadly roof insulation, faulty solar panel installations, and the vocational and training college rorts. Our bushfire victims deserve better than this.

Glenn Hilling, Watsonia North

The choice where to live

Old saying to sharks: "I won't swim in your ocean if you don't swim in my pool". The same may be analogous of people who choose to live in the volatile Australian bush.

Greg Reiffel, Hoppers Crossing

Dangerous chemicals

Climate change deniers may argue that pollutants produced by the burning of fossil fuels are not affecting the climate. However, what is difficult to deny is that some chemicals released from myriad human activities have been found in the tissues of wildlife in remote parts of the planet far away from their source.

Some of these chemicals have been detected in the air we breathe, the water we drink, the breast milk we feed our young, the food we eat, and even some of our body tissues. Whether they play a role in the development of any of the dozens of unexplained cancers and autoimmune diseases remains to be determined but seems likely.Alfred Poulos,

retired professor of genetics/biochemistry, Thornbury

Importance of language

Are the 2019-20 Victorian bushfires "unprecedented" given thus far that three lives have been lost, and 1.2 million hectares, 110 homes and 220 outbuildings have been burnt (The Age 5/1)? Fire has been present for millions of years.

According to the Forest Fire Management Victoria website: In terms of total area burnt, the 1851 (5 million hectares) and 1939 (1.5 to 2 million hectares) fires were larger. The 2006-07 (1.2 million hectares) and 2003 (1.3 million hectares) fires were comparable. Black Saturday 2009 (173 lives) and Black Friday 1939 (71 lives) led to greater loss of life. In 2009, 2000 properties and 80 businesses were burnt. Make no mistake, these are big, intense fires but let us be careful about the language used to describe them.

Stephen Platt, Rosanna

A culture to be proud of

Acknowledging the wisdom of Aboriginal practices, such as cultural burning, respecting the land and adopting traditional agricultural practices, would go a long way towards preventing future bushfire disasters. We have arrogantly ignored Aboriginal wisdom for the past 200 or so years. Embracing this ancient culture and forming a treaty with our Indigenous Australians would give us all a culture to be proud of, and a significant date that would give genuine meaning to the term "Australia Day". We are the only commonwealth country that has failed to form a treaty with its Indigenous population.

Sue Lyons, Carlton North

The pollies we need

The fires have seen so many Australians respond magnificently with empathy, generosity, courage and action. This has won them admiration and respect. How happy it would be if our politicians, especially the party hierarchies, responded in ways that won for them that same community regard. Dare we hope?

Murray Ainsworth,

Hawthorn East

Welcome all our refugees

As I watched HMAS Choules rescue refugees from burning Mallacoota, it occurred to me how cruel it would be to use it to turn refugees back to where they came from, or incarcerate them in a distant island, in order to deter others wanting to escape similar fires. That is what we have done with refugees seeking the safety of our shores. Perhaps it is time for some of the empathy we feel for our countrymen to ripple to those outside our borders, as people from overseas feel for us now.

We could bring all the refugees from New Guinea and Nauru to Australia, where they could provide valuable support to our exhausted survivors. The many millions of dollars spent on keeping them idle could be used to diminish our coming deficit. And if they felt like staying in this country, they could help in the massive rebuilding to come. We certainly do not need them to suffer in order to deter others from coming to our shores. Our country does not look very appealing at the moment.

Paul Valent, South Yarra

Fair go for Boomers

Some sympathy goes to your editors in trying to find a suitable headline - "Blame new era of low growth, low rates on Boomers" (Business, 9/1) - to fit the complexities of Stephen Bartholomeusz' take on the economy. However, please spare us the tired blaming and labelling of a particular generation.

John Phillips, Carlton North

Please, give us a break

John Meaney (Letters, 9/1), I could not agree more with your comment about annoying advertisements on television. My mute button was hit nine times the other night. Not only does the ad annoy me beyond measure, it is the number of times that it is on. I will never use that advertiser.

Val Hyde, Blackburn North

urn:contentItem:5XXT-5851-F0J6-J3WK-00000-00LETTERS2020-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:43ZLexisNexisOPINIONLettersPg. 18LETTERS

Misplaced fuel reduction

Scott Morrison's comments on fuel reduction suggest he has as little understanding of forest fire science as he has of climate science. Many scientific studies have shown that under extreme climatic conditions, fuel reduction burning will have little impact on bushfire severity and that burning well away from human assets will do little to protect them.

Daniel Andrews correctly stated that burning off must only be done in strategic areas to protect human assets. Victoria's policy was developed after comprehensive reviews of the Black Saturday royal commission's recommendations.

Fuel reduction burning is only effective in moderating fire behaviour under milder weather conditions and for the first few years after burning. It does many undesirable things, such as destroying plant and animal species and wildlife habitat, creating more flammable forests, and increasing death of vegetation by promoting disease fungi.

A focus on fuel reduction seems badly misplaced when 90 per cent of all fires in Victoria are caused by people - 27 per cent of such fires are due to arsonists and 63 per cent are due to accidents.Michael Feller (professor emeritus, faculty of forestry, University of British Columbia), Healesville

In favour of burning

The argument that fuel reduction burns are pointless because they have failed to stop fires under extreme conditions is akin to arguing that seatbelt laws are useless because drivers wearing seatbelts have been killed in car accidents. Both measures are of benefit during most conditions.

Nick Barton, Hillside

Lessons from disasters

Amid the devastation of the bushfires and subsequent analysis and political blaming, it is important to celebrate that so many people heeded the emergency warnings and left areas of extreme danger. Technology - such as the VicEmergency app - has been used for accurate forecasting of weather and fire behaviour, and that has enabled accurate warnings to the public.

We now lament the loss of property and infrastructure, forest, wildlife and stock, and tragically mourn the loss of two people's lives in Victoria. Let us give thanks that the number of fatalities have been so few in contrast to Ash Wednesday and Black Saturday. Much was learnt from those disasters and that has surely saved many in the face of this crisis.Christine Sebire,

Echuca

Disaster management 101

When the going gets tough, the tough ... make an advertisement, get public endorsement from John Howard, and announce a review to be conducted by Philip Ruddock. Two out of three so far.

Richard Clarke, Malvern

Sport stars with big hearts

Sam Duncan (Comment, 7/1) rightly commends our sports stars, headed by Nick Kyrgios, for their wonderful support for the bushfire victims. This shows that as well as their amazing talent, they also have, in spades, empathy, generosity and a true Christian spirit. I wonder if Israel Folau has dipped into his multimillion-dollar payout and shown us the real meaning of his Christianity?

Liz Harvey, Mount Eliza

Manage money well. . .

With so many agencies and individuals donating money to bushfire victims, there needs to be a central fund to collect donations. Otherwise how can the public be assured their donations are really going to the most needy cases? The fund could be controlled and audited by an accounting firm. Local councils could quickly distribute the funds as they have the best knowledge of properties which have been affected.

David Fry, Moonee Ponds

. . . and avoid duplication

Why do our political leaders think that creating more agencies is the correct response to recovery from the fires? My experience as a very senior CFA officer was that locals are best able to manage the recovery process.

Councils may not be perfect for some purposes but they do perform extremely well in times of trauma and emergency because they understand the needs of their people. They will allocate any funds provided to them quickly, fairly and to greatest benefit of the affected communities. We do not need more bureaucracy to complicate and duplicate the established recovery arrangements.Ian Symons,

Drouin

The timing isn't right

The climate change activists who plan to protest on Friday lack understanding and consideration for the emergency services and the people who have been traumatised by the bushfires. There is no valid reason as to why this protest cannot be held in a few weeks' time. Why not have a media boycott of the event but a promise to cover protests that are held in the future?Ellen Mcgregor,

Frankston

The fires' economic cost

How many beehives have been lost in the fires across the country? Agriculture and dairy products as well as honey supplies will be in short supply over the coming months. Food costs for everyone will rise. Fewer people will dine out. Cafes and restaurants will feel the pinch. Jobs will inevitably go. Just think what a forward-thinking and planning government could have done. And as for Craig Kelly on British television. He is a walking denial disaster.

Elaine O'Shannessy, Buxton

Getting our comeuppance

All those United Nations representatives and the like who have had to listen to Australia's excuses for its lack of action on climate change and who mourn with us now as Australia burns. I wonder, can we Aussies blame them if the thought pops up in their heads: "It serves them right".

Judie Litchfield,

Sandringham

Ignore any further advice

So the Prime Minister has been "consulting his mentor John Howard" about the fires (Letters, 7/1). In further mentoring, will Howard blindly recommend Australia's ongoing and unwinnable involvement in Donald Trump's escalating Middle East hostilities? As Howard himself gave ignorant support to Tony Blair's and George W. Bush's "weapons of mass destruction".

Karen Fry, Bairnsdale

Protecting his children

Will any of Donald Trump's sons or daughters go to war, or are bone spurs hereditary?

Richard Hughes, Woodend

Act now to avoid war

Former presidents of the United States must now band together, regardless of their political affiliations, and demand that Congress immediately censure Donald Trump's irrational behaviour and enable emergency legislation preventing actions from the White House that can escalate further tensions in the Middle East and beyond.

Maurie Johns, Mount Eliza

Our voice of desperation

Australia begging to stay in Iraq (The Age, 8/1): "Please don't make me leave. Remember I came to save you from a dictator and give you democracy, regardless of the United Nations' wishes. Your economy and infrastructure may be in ruins, many Iraqis have died needlessly but I am your willing coalition friend. Please let me stay."Ludi Servadei,

Malvern East

Reneging on agreement

It looks like there will be another war in the Middle East and hundreds of thousands of people may die, with millions displaced. Why? There was an agreement in place, with the United States a party to it. The US reneged on it and imposed severe sanctions on Iran. Australia, despite supporting this agreement, as did most of the world, remained quiet regarding the unilateral repudiation of it.

Withdrawal from the agreement was instigated and supported by two leaders who have been subject to criminal investigations and, but for the technicality of immunity due to incumbency, might have been prosecuted and jailed under their own judicial systems. In that case, war would not be an issue.

Carlo Ursida, Kensington

Don't 'average out' cricket

We might be talking about "salvaging the classic form of the game by shortening it", Greg Baum (Sport, 7/1), but at the risk of savaging Test cricket. Women's Tests are played over four days and are so undervalued as a spectacle that they are infrequently scheduled. The fifth day is not a bonus day; it sets the parameters of the game as it unfolds, giving rise to a declaration, or enforcing the opponents to follow-on, to substantial run partnerships and valiant individual scores, with changes in the pitch (and weather) integral to the long form.

Test cricket is a battle of minds and bodies with long practised skills, session after session, where neither team may win after five days but a long fight to draw can be its own victory. If, as Baum suggests, the move is an attempt to "average out cricket" across all shortened forms, I fear that we will end up with average cricket.

Lisa Frazer, Templestowe

Sportsmanship, NZ style

We may have won the recent cricket Test series against New Zealand but the Kiwis won hands down when it came to sportsmanship. There was little or no sledging. When Marcus Labuschagne reached 200, many of the Kiwi fielders applauded him and when he was finally out, several ran over to him as he was leaving the field and congratulated him. Haven't seen that in a long time.John Cummings, Anglesea

Enough with the ads

Could The Age please run a poll on the most annoying advertisements on television. I used to enjoy sitting down at night with a glass of wine to watch my favourite programs. Now I sit with the remote control ready to hit the mute button when a certain ad for hotel bookings comes on. At least with a newspaper advertisement, you can skip it if it is of no interest to you but an annoying TV ad just makes you respond negatively to that advertiser.John Meaney,

Frankston South

urn:contentItem:5YCT-P751-F031-X1FM-00000-00How bushfire survivors are coping2020-03-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:43ZLexisNexis7.308:27 PM AESTABCLucy CarterHow bushfire survivors are coping

FIRE FIGHTER: Spot-fires galore down here. We are talking about 60, 70 metre flame heights, 60, 70 metre flame heights.

FIRE FIGHTER: Get into the water, it's chaos. I've never seen anything like it.

LUCY CARTER, REPORTER: Thousands of people right across Australia had their lives changed forever this summer.

On New Year's Eve, fire all but wiped Cobargo off the map.

JADE CORBY, COBARGO RESIDENT: So we were going around, my brother and my brother-in-law were going around and that, putting out spot fires and protecting what they could, when they could.

LUCY CARTER: As the fire front approached, Jade Corby, his wife and two sons fled to his brother's house on the outskirts of Cobargo.

JADE CORBY: Until it got that bad that it was right up against the house and then we all just come back, fell back to the house and just looked after the house.

LUCY CARTER: His own family home and most of his livestock were wiped out.

JADE CORBY: Strange when you see what it left, what it took. Just little things you'd find that it didn't burn.

The young fella's little four-wheeler motorbike is sitting only probably five metres from the house and the fire burnt right around it and everything. Didn't even burn tyres off it. It's still sitting there and the house and the ground, you know, there is nothing left of the house.

LUCY CARTER: Life is slowly returning to normal for the Corby's. They now rent a property a few kilometres from where their old home used to stand.

JADE CORBY: It hasn't been easy but there's a lot of people that are worse off out there.

A lot of families that are harder done by but we were all safe so that was the main thing.

LUCY CARTER: This bushfire season has been nothing short of extraordinary. More than 8 million hectares of land has burned, 33 people have died, and more than 2,500 homes destroyed.

An unexpectedly early and severe start to Queensland's fire season was quickly followed by fatal fires on the New South Wales North Coast.

ROB ROGERS, DEPUTY COMMISSIONER, NSW RURAL FIRE SERVICE: We're having extreme fire danger and I think that's unprecedented at this time of year in the state.

LUCY CARTER: Dry lightning in the New South Wales Blue Mountains ignited a blaze that would later become the nation's biggest ever forest fire.

Massive blazes in almost every Australian state and territory followed, with temperature records shattered and thousands of homes lost.

GLADYS BEREJIKLIAN, PREMIER OF NEW SOUTH WALES: I have accepted the advice of Commissioner Fitzsimmons and declared a state of emergency.

LUCY CARTER: The New Year saw Australians cowering on beaches under blood-red skies and the Defence Force called in for emergency evacuations.

LISA NEVILLE, VICTORIAN MINISTER FOR POLICE AND EMERGENCY SERVICES: I wish I could say this was over, but we've still got a long way to go.

LUCY CARTER: Widespread rain finally extinguished most of the fires in early February, but officially this fire season isn't over yet.

SHANE FITZSIMMONS, RFS COMMISSIONER: There is no doubt that this season is unprecedented in terms of the fire danger ratings that we experienced, the ones that were forecast and realised, and then, of course, the amount of area that was burnt by fire.

LUCY CARTER: The New South Wales Rural Fire Service Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons has been at the front-line of this disaster from the beginning.

SHANE FITZSIMMONS: The damage, and death toll particularly, has had a profound effect on all of us that are involved here in New South Wales and right across the country.

LUCY CARTER: Six firefighters are among the dead. It's a burden he shoulders daily.

SHANE FITZSIMMONS: And the lives of people have changed forever as a result of this fire season.

DAINTRY GERRAND: Little herbaceous, native herbaceous things coming back from seed.

LUCY CARTER: For Daintry and Ian Gerrand, life will never be the same.

DAINTRY GERRAND: Yeah, well you can see, if we hadn't taken out the canopy cover between this big tree, the lilly pilly, and the house, it would have carried right through to the house and been a totally different story.

LUCY CARTER: They almost lost their home in the November blaze that swept through the tiny town of Johns River.

DAINTRY GERRAND: When that wind change hit, it would have been kilometres away from us before the change and then it just blew that out and rushed through in minutes.

LUCY CARTER: A greater danger was facing Daintry's sister, Julie Fletcher, less than two kilometres down the road.

They couldn't reach her.

DAINTRY GERRAND: We left a light on, so the fire truck could find the house and then I rang Julie again but it was too late.

She said that the fire, you know, had come.

LUCY CARTER: When did you hear about what had happened to Julie?

DAINTRY GERRAND: I knew when the phone went dead. Well, in my heart I knew.

But, it wasn't until, well, it wasn't until the early hours of the morning that I was able to get confirmation that the house had burnt down.

Julie loved the farm and she loved that it was a beautiful environment down there, it was a family farm.

She was caring. Julie was a really caring and compassionate lady.

LUCY CARTER: What do you want Australians to know about preparing their homes for bushfire?

DAINTRY GERRAND: I think we need to all think about how we redesign the gardens around our house, to give us a more defendable space. That space around the house is really important.

PROFESSOR ROSS BRADSTOCK, UNIVERSITY OF WOLLONGONG: I don't think it's the new normal, but I think it's possibly an indication of the new extreme. Well, a five million or six million hectare season may be the new extreme event.

LUCY CARTER: Ahead of this bushfire season large areas of south-eastern Australia were identified as being extremely dry and vulnerable to fire.

These maps, produced exclusively for 7.30, show how alarmingly accurate those predictions were.

Forecasters were still shocked by the amount of land that eventually burned.

ROSS BRADSTOCK: We've literally had an unprecedented area burned. As of mid-January about 21 per cent of the forests in south-eastern Australia burned and if we examine similar forests elsewhere in the world, the best figure we can come up with in the last 20 years is about 10 per cent.

LUCY CARTER: While the Federal Government is pushing for increased hazard reduction burning, Professor Ross Bradstock says it may not be the best or most cost effective way to reduce the risk of fire.

ROSS BRADSTOCK: We might be better off spending money on retro-fitting houses. We might be better off actually modifying vegetation permanently, particularly around the interface between developments and flammable bushland.

We know that the 50 metres or so around houses is absolutely critical.

LUCY CARTER: Professor Bradstock says climate change means Australians are going to have to come to terms with increased fire danger.

ROSS BRADSTOCK: The risks posed by bushfires can't be eliminated. They can be mitigated, or reduced to some degree, but that's expensive and it means educating people to understand that there is some background level of risk.

SHANE FITZSIMMONS: There are legitimate health concerns with polluted air, with smoke in the air.

The reality is we have got to have a sensible conversation because I can't burn the bush without smoke coming from it. A by-product of combustion is actual smoke and whilst ever we're burning the landscape, and it's an effective tool to help manage fuel loads, whilst it is not an panacea, it it's an effective tool, it has side effects.

LUCY CARTER: Kangaroo Island, off the coast of South Australia, has been one of the worst affected areas.

It's been about two months since fire ripped through and destroyed more than half of the island, but so many residents are still struggling.

They are camping on their own land and relying on handouts to stay afloat.

JADE HINTON: It's unbelievable. Most of what I've seen out the west end here, like people's properties, have just been annihilated and they've got nothing, nothing left.

LUCY CARTER: Jade Hinton is running a makeshift recovery centre for the west of the island from the change rooms of the sports club.

JADE HINTON: This is them here. Do you reckon you would use the smaller ones?

LUCY CARTER: She was on the island for a Christmas holiday when the fires started. Almost three months later, Jade is still here.

JADE HINTON: They're so reliant on what we've got here. I think if we didn't have this, people would be struggling big time.

RYAN COUCHMAN: Yeah, it's a game changer. The community's never seen anything like this before.

LUCY CARTER: Ryan Couchman estimates the Kangaroo Island fires caused more than a million dollars' worth of damage to his farm.

RYAN COUCHMAN: We lost all of our pasture, we've lost all of our fences. We've lost between 800 and 900 sheep.

So basically all we're left with here is the workshop and most of the machinery. Everything else is gone - house, shearing shed, sheds, cars, machinery.

LUCY CARTER: Like so many around Australia, he's going to be hand feeding his surviving animals for months. Getting this farm operational again will take years.

RYAN COUCHMAN: So going back to a working farm, like we had beforehand, with our shearing sheds and obviously having a house where you can live on-site, is going to make it pretty difficult.

LUCY CARTER: Further west on the edge of Kangaroo Island, Kyra Phillips and her partner, Robert Engelbarts, are still coming to terms with the destruction around them.

ROBERT ENGELBARTS: I still can't control myself as far as crying. Every time I think of it, because it's just...

So many animals, didn't stand a chance. Like when we came in here, we found a kangaroo that was blinded on the side of the road. How's that going to survive?

LUCY CARTER: The couple are camping in the ruins of the farm stay they used to manage.

ROBERT ENGELBARTS: We lost virtually everything, to be honest. We just took, like, one bag with our passports and etc, and a change of clothes.

KYRA PHILLIPS: There is families that are underinsured that have children that can't rebuild their homes.

Where are they going to be in six months' time? That's what us, as a community, is worried about.

LUCY CARTER: Like so many right across Australia's burned south-east, they're unsure of what the future now holds.

What's clear is that the recovery will be a long road.

JADE CORBY: Resilience to me means family and keeping going for the family and keeping strong for the family.

You know, family means everything to me and that's, I suppose, the thing that keeps me going the most.

urn:contentItem:62FR-PRJ1-JD34-V4PP-00000-00Down the rabbit hole2021-04-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:43ZLexisNexisGOOD WEEKENDPg. 12Down the rabbit holeFrank Robson

Conspiracy theories have become a mental contagion, a global game of sorts fuelled by social media and weaponised by celebrities and politicians. More interesting than the theories themselves, however, are how individuals get drawn into their thrall.

IT'S THE day of Joe Biden's inauguration as US President, and conspiracy hives around the world are abuzz with news of his imminent arrest as part of a military coup. As usual, details are vague and sources unnamed. Yet online conspiracy feeders gobble it up, believing Biden's arrest - for "illegal dealings", or something - will lead, somehow or other, to Donald Trump's return as leader of the free world.

And why wouldn't they?

Trump told them repeatedly that he was the greatest president ever. And, despite everything, they believed it. He told them the US election was "stolen", and they should march on Capitol Hill in protest, and they believed that, too - with fatal consequences for five people.

Now, just hours before Biden is due to be sworn in as America's 46th president at 3.30am on January 21 (AEST), self-proclaimed "Truthers" are once more united in their belief that this is conspiracy movement QAnon's promised "Great Awakening" or "The Storm", when Trump will expose a cabal of Satan-worshipping paedophile cannibal liberal elites, and that Biden and Vice-President Kamala Harris will never make it to the White House.

"There's millions of us who hope [martial law] will actually start tomorrow," I'm told by veteran Australian conspiracist Jeni Edgley the day before it's all supposed to happen. "Some believe Biden will be arrested as he is inaugurated ... Trump wants to cause the least amount of damage to the military and the American people. That's why everything has been kept under wraps."

Like others who buy this stuff, Edgley (once married to showbiz tycoon Michael Edgley) sounds thrilled to possess information at odds with what she scornfully calls "The Narrative" - meaning pretty much everything the rest of us accept as factual.

At 70, the anti-vaxxer and former natural health practitioner lives in retirement in North Queensland. Although I tell her I'm interested only in how she came to be a believer, she soon swamps my phone with the type of videos she recycles ad infinitum via her social media feeds.

Most are from extreme right or religious sources in the US, and include the usual QAnon rants about mass murders committed by the Clintons; the COVID-19 "conspiracy"; Michelle Obama's secret life as a transgender male; "proof" of how the US election was stolen ... and so on.

I ask Edgley if I can call her again around the time of Biden's inauguration to talk about whatever's happening.

She agrees, but points out that she's been advised via a "10-second clip from some military person" that because of "worldwide social media censorship", and the distortions of mainstream hacks like me, Trump will be launching an alternative broadcasting system to tell people about the coup.

"We're all supposed to switch to this emergency system worldwide," she says. "So you and I may not be able to call each other."

That night, watching eerie scenes of the empty US capitol in security lockdown, I'm torn between confidence that nothing will happen, and concern (based on televised repeats of the insane Washington riot just a fortnight earlier) that anything could happen.

Edgley's first message, opting out of our planned chat, arrives at 8.30pm. An hour later, she elaborates: "Hi Frank, There is SO much going on ... I'm receiving a post a minute from all over the world. I'm loving seeing all the complexities of different viewpoints and don't want to miss a moment ... I don't want to be sharing this time (I've waited for over 40 years) with a serious journalist! ... I just want to 'be' with it all."

Edgley isn't sure when the military coup will unfold, but suggests Trump's farewell speech earlier in the day - "The movement we started is only just beginning ... the best is yet to come!" âˆ’ is a likely pointer to what's about to happen.

"TO THAT EXTENT," she concludes, "I WON'T BE AVAILABLE FOR CALLS TONIGHT."

To my horror, she sends another raft of fact-free videos: a bald English charlatan spruiking the sale of gold and silver; a Fox News "exposé" involving China; predictions of soaring death rates from COVID vaccinations, and something Edgley labels "the selling of aborted baby parts illegally".

By 4am the following day, Biden and Harris have been sworn in without incident, and I go to sleep soothed by a classic by the Scottish band Del Amitri that could serve as QAnon's theme song: And nothing ever happens, nothing happens at all The needle returns to the start of the song And we all sing along like before... Much later, I find a message Edgley sent at 4.45 am: "Yes, I was up all night ... devastated. Can't believe nothing happened ... such a corrupt group of individuals back in power !!!!!! The tentacles run deep! ... I don't believe a word of their ceremony ... [they] said all the right words [but] I've seen [too] much about them from Hunter Biden with his 'crack pipe' and having sex with his niece to Michelle Obama being a transvestite. Signing off ... exhausted and saddened."

Another message that afternoon says she's been in touch with lots of other Truthers equally stricken by the failure of "good" to prevail over "evil", presumably by destroying the world's largest democracy before their eyes. But she watched a couple of old conspiracy videos and felt a little better - "or have we all been sucked in ... as I believe you feel we all have ..." After that, with her question yet unanswered, Edgley goes to ground - "fasting and meditating". It's almost three weeks before I hear from her again.

NONE OF this orchestrated craziness is new to me.

When I was a kid, my father - a conspiracy theorist all his adult life - became convinced a man camped in scrub near our house had been sent to murder him by fiendish Jewish plotters for One World Government. (He turned out to be just a lonely man with a ready ear for conspiracy theories.) I've written before about the toll Dad's mania took on our family ("My Father the Fascist", Good Weekend, March 8, 2019). Yet even in his wildest imaginings I doubt that FNick, as my brother and I called our war-damaged father, could have envisaged what conspiracy theories would look like by 2021.

Waves of corrosive bullshit lash the planet, driven by the unholy confluence of internet, Trump and pandemic. Fear, aggression and monumental stupidity conspire to swamp science and reason; truth and accuracy are shouted down by people who think facts are "points of view" and that watching YouTube propaganda videos is research.

"If I trust the scientist and you trust the guy on YouTube," says Roland Imhoff, a social psychologist at Germany's Johannes Gutenberg University, "there's no common ground between us. And having a shared understanding of reality is essential to society. Without it, there is no truth anymore. That's a huge danger."

Long before the web gave credible scientists and credulous YouTube researchers equal access to global audiences, FNick was evolving and pushing his favoured theories - Jewish plots, Holocaust denial, anti-vaccination, anti-fluoridation - in the old way. An experienced journalist, he read a lot (in support of what he already believed), communicated by mail with obscure right-wing bookstores and fellow believers, addressed public gatherings and plagued newspaper editors with the racist, anti-science screeds that clattered almost daily from his typewriter.

FNick died in 1987, aged 93, still fighting to spur a then largely indifferent world to action before it was "too late". Most of his awful beliefs survived, as they had for centuries before him, and have now been given comic book touches for the social media crowd. Dad was a societal outsider: bombastic, contrary, distrustful of governments and scornful of all opposing views.

Most of these traits, along with anxiety, depression and impulsiveness, are emerging through research as indicative of the modern conspiracy mindset.

"[Studies show] up to 80 per cent of people now believe in at least one conspiracy theory," Dr Mathew Marques, a lecturer in social psychology at Melbourne's La Trobe University, tells Good Weekend. "They usually involve a group of malevolent people having covered something up, although there's no evidence of that having occurred."

Increasingly, Marques suggests, committed conspiracists tend to "interpret any and all events as part of some conspiracy ... when they don't find evidence of the thing they believe in, they just move on to the next thing ... the current level of scepticism [over science and established facts] is just off the rails, off the charts."

Of course, lots of things in the world aren't what they seem to be: vested interests influence wars, economies and elections; politicians and governments lie and cheat in the name of expedience. But this has little to do with the current crop of conspiracy theories, which seem more like part of a mental contagion than shared concern over actual wrongs or injustices.

Some identify the contagion as QAnon itself. The movement began in 2017 with a series of posts from an anonymous user on the message board 4Chan. Claiming to have a level of US security approval known as "Q clearance", the user signed off as "Q". By a process too asinine to dwell on, this reportedly led to today's QAnon: essentially a pro-Trump propaganda machine, built around its own inaugural lie about Trump fighting an heroic war against a network of child-trafficking Democrats and Hollywood elites.

QAnon's cryptic, coded fabrications are now feverishly "interpreted" by legions of devotees. Perhaps coincidentally, the movement gained ever wider audiences as sections of the global media abandoned actual news gathering in favour of propagandised "entertainment".

Why do grown people take this stuff seriously? Even more perplexing, why do they keep believing when - time after time - the conspiracies and their authors fail to be publicly "revealed" as predicted? In a lot of cases, believers seem unaware they're being politically manipulated, or lack even a basic understanding of the political divisions involved.

After ploughing through hours of Australian social media feeds, my feeling is that conspiracies have become a sort of global, online "game". Some get involved because it suits their beliefs, but others play the game because they like the idea of themselves as "independent thinkers" who see through the deceptions fed to "sheeples" and "normies" by corrupt governments and scientific institutions. This isn't a story about the theories themselves, but an attempt to understand how people are drawn into their thrall.

BUSINESSMAN EMMANUEL Goubert was in his 20s and attending business school in France when the scales of conventional belief began falling from his eyes and attaching themselves to giant, bloodthirsty lizards. "If you'd told me [before then] that the world was controlled by an elite that controls all the wealth ... and that these guys are actually of extra-terrestrial origin, and that their ... god is a demon, and they do a lot of sacrifices of kids, and blood rituals, I would tell you, 'Man, just go back in your box! I don't want to hear it!' " He'd have thought they were crazy?

Goubert: "Oh, 100 per cent!" And now?

"Now I [know] the real lie was the lie I was living in since I was born, which is so huge and so disgusting ..." Goubert, 32, moved to Australia from France eight years ago. He lives with his partner on North Stradbroke Island, near Brisbane, where he operates an importexport business from their home at Point Lookout. He's intelligent, good looking, polite, well-travelled ... and absolutely committed to outlandish conspiracy theories.

His core belief is that the world has been controlled for thousands of years by shape-shifting aliens. They live underground and follow what another writer has called a "marvellously slow" plan for the ultimate enslavement of humanity.

"They are called draco reptilians. They are from three to four metres tall, can weigh up to 200 kilograms, and they feed on fear and blood," Goubert explains gravely.

"They are the mosquitoes of the universe."

Apart from the lizards, this sounds strangely familiar.

I tell Goubert how my father believed in an ancient Jewish plot to enslave humanity through a crippling system of "false debt".

"Yes," he says. "That is correct."

It turns out that Goubert's space lizards are aided and abetted by Jews, who are the wealth-controlling elite he mentioned earlier. FNick's old favourite has been rejigged over the years, largely by mega conspiracy spreader David Icke, a former soccer player and BBC sports presenter who was banned from entering Australia in 2019. On social media, Icke has variously blamed Jews for the pandemic, linked it to the 5G mobile network, claimed that COVID-19 can't be transmitted via physical contact, and played down the infectiousness of viruses in general.

On his public Facebook page, Goubert reposts daily updates from extreme-right sources, including the pro-Trump "Enemies of the People" movement. He tells me he's from a "traditional" French family in Bayonne, and that his geologistteacher mother and builder father support and share his beliefs.

He provides their names, and the name of his Australian partner, but later insists that only his name, in a reduced form, be used in this story.

He says even he wouldn't have spoken out in the past through fear he would be ridiculed, or "have an accident tomorrow and just disappear from the planet". (Using his full name in Facebook posts doesn't seem to trouble him.) Belief in extraterrestrial visitations apparently came to his "spiritual, meditating" father long before Goubert himself embraced the reptile plot, largely through his membership of Gaia - a streaming service that focuses on pseudoscience, yoga, conspiracy theories and alternative medicine.

"When my father was young, he and his sisters saw UFOs above a property in France," he says. Much later, when Goubert told his father he'd come to believe the world was controlled by aliens, and that he feared he was "going crazy", his father confessed to having reached a similar conclusion years earlier. (He'd kept it to himself through fear of ridicule.) "All of the true stuff is ridiculed," says Goubert, echoing one of FNick's recurring laments. (I remember our mother actually running away when he was laughed at while banging on about The Plot in public.) "People just laugh about it," Goubert tells me. "They tell us, 'It's all just bullshit, har, har, har!' And the har-har-har is the biggest weapon that has always been used to stop people seeing the truth."

His reaction has been to cut himself off from all credible news sources. This began involuntarily in 2001 when his father, outraged by the media "spreading fear" about the Twin Towers terrorism attack, seized the family's only TV set and threw it into the street.

Goubert, who thinks terrorism is "another agenda from the New World Order", insists he hasn't used any conventional news outlets since that day. He's somehow aware, though, that all the news he misses is "manipulated" by aliens via their Jewish lackeys.

Goubert gets most of his information from Gaia, YouTube and other internet sources, and the rest from books with "spiritual" or extra-terrestrial themes recommended within his online "community". He thinks almost everything taught in conventional schools is alien lies, and estimates that since he turned to conspiracy theories, roughly 90 per cent of those he considers friends are people he hasn't met in person.

"There is a lot of disinformation on the internet," he concedes, adding, "but when you know where to look, it's incredible. It has allowed people to open their minds and be receptive to new possibilities faster."

Goubert has opened his mind to most QAnon fabrications, including the claim that COVID-19 was deliberately created (with its vaccines set to kill more people than the virus itself) as part of "a strategy to get less people on the planet and then control them all".

He sees himself and fellow believers as "soldiers" for the cause, and seems genuinely confused by the difference between fact and fantasy. "Younger people are really open to all this [conspiracy] stuff," he enthuses.

"And [because of] all these alien and hero and superpower movies, when you start talking to them about the possibility of having aliens on the planet, these guys are already saying, 'Yeah, of course. Why not?' " AMONG AUSTRALIA'S busiest spreaders of QAnon material is a 60-something couples counsellor who calls herself the "Love Coach". The description sits oddly on her public Facebook page above hateful rants accusing legally innocent people of crimes including mass murder, paedophilia, political assassinations, embezzlement, treason, sedition and drug dealing.

And that was just on a single day during the pre-inauguration conspiracy frenzy, when she shared a series of baseless claims - "From a Marine at CIA headquarters" - against the Clintons, George Bush snr, Barack Obama, Dick Cheney and others. Since then, she's maintained her daily habit of sharing propaganda, especially fear-mongering anti-vaxxer themes, almost hourly with her 1900-plus Facebook followers.

No fan of the established media, which she calls "treasonous ... brainwashed, blackmailed scum", the Love Coach nonetheless boasts on her website of having promoted her services via the ABC, 2UE, 2GB, the Daily Telegraph and Cosmopolitan magazine.

When I phone her at her NSW home, she agrees to discuss how she became a conspiracy theorist but only if her name isn't used. I tell her that wouldn't make sense because she's already using her name to publicly accuse people of serious crimes.

LC: "So you're actually using real names?" Me: "Of course ... And real facts."

LC says it would be dangerous for her to use her name because US authorities are shutting down social media sites if people even "mention anything like antivaccination ... I seem to have got away with it on Facebook for some obscure reason."

Me: "You're worried about your privacy, yet you're happy to accuse people of murder on a public forum?" LC: "Yeah, I'm completely happy to suggest that somebody has been paedophiling [sic] children and committing heinous crimes ... when there's enormous amounts of proof around."

Me: "What sort of evidence do you need before sharing this stuff?" LC: "I need about five bits of information from top level sources ... [such as] people who have access to M16, CIA, umm - white-hat stuff, Q stuff which has access to military intelligence."

She suggests that if the "utterly biased" mainstream media wanted balance, it would regularly allow Truthers to comment on issues of the day. "Truthers," she adds, "is a better word than conspiracy theorists because they're not conspiracy theories, they're conspiracy facts, most of them." She insists that, "along with all the other Trumpers", she is just a private person who "really believes in the truth".

Me: "Do you believe the US election was stolen?" LC: "Without a skerrick of a doubt, yes."

Me: "Okay, well I think the reality is there's not much hope for you. But thanks anyway." A few minutes after the call ends, the Love Coach fires back in a text: "You're obviously not very skilled at building trust - a valuable asset in these days."

Central to this peculiar alliance are Kelly's promotion of unproven COVID therapies on social media, and his appearance in a podcast hosted by controversial celebrity chef and anti-vaxxer Pete Evans.

Kelly quit the Liberal Party in February after being rebuked by PM Scott Morrison for posting misinformation about COVID on social media.

He now occupies the crossbench.

Global health authorities are troubled by the extent of misinformation about COVID vaccines, and are countering with online fact sheets about the immunisation process and gee-ups from prominent people. "Research teams are also looking at ways of trying to train people to identify misinformation through things like online games," says social psychologist Mathew Marques.

"They show how people use conspiracy theories and other forms of misinformation for gain and profit.

Hopefully, this kind of research can be expanded to schools ... because the concern is that this sort of thing isn't going away anytime soon."

JENI EDGLEY is a fan of both Kelly and Evans. In the '70s and '80s, she and impresario Michael Edgley were the power couple of Australian show business.

They ran the multimillion-dollar entertainment business, Michael Edgley International, owned a series of mansions in Perth and Sydney, drove a yellow Rolls, hung out with the rich and famous, and captivated the media.

"Jeni Edgley has deep brown eyes, dark circles under them, and a cheeky smile," ran a piece in The Australian Women's Weekly in 1981. "She is instantly likeable. She talks and smokes furiously and is as down to earth in her conversation as in her clothing."

She qualified as a naturopath in Sydney, parted from Michael in the late 1980s, and started her Hideaway Health Retreat in the Gold Coast hinterland soon afterwards.

Intrigued, even then, by fringe beliefs, she hosted "Nitty Gritty" days at the retreat, where guest speakers lectured on UFOs, yowies, the Loch Ness monster, lost cities, the JFK assassination, and the sins of the medical establishment. "In my knowledge," Edgley told a Good Weekend writer in 1996, "there are three people who have come up with cures for cancer which were banned because they didn't fit in with medical orthodoxy."

But later, after watching "thousands of hours" of conspiracy videos on the theme, she accepted QAnon claims about Trump fighting a global child abuse ring.

Trump, she adds, "always reminds me of my ex [Michael Edgley] ... I mean, in that money is his life, and deals and negotiations and all that sorta stuff.

So I know his sort of character."

They're also reposting claims that martial law and the Insurrection Act have already been invoked, and that Biden isn't really president. Does Edgley still believe this crap?

"Yes," she says, without hesitation.

"Oh, Jeni," I groan. "Surely not!" "If it isn't true," she demands, "how come Biden hasn't been seen on Air Force One? And how come military people are turning their backs and not saluting him?" (Writing of the conspiracist mind in the London Review of Books last October, British novelist James Meek counsels against arguing with believers: "You're faced with a choice between challenging limitless errors one by one, or denouncing an entire edifice of belief ... It's like a forest fire that can only be put out one square inch at a time, or all at once, and so can never be put out.") Which is a pity. Because the AWW was right: Jeni Edgley is likeable. When she isn't plunging down mad rabbit holes. "Listen to that beautiful storm!" she hollers at one stage, pacing the garden with her phone as a thunderstorm rumbles in. I even like that she still smokes - an outrageous habit for a health advisor, alternative or not, yet in keeping with her maverick disposition. At times, she even manages a nod to the absurdity of conspiracist thinking. "I told my son I was frightened [the authorities] were going to come after me [for reposting conspiracy theories]," she recalls.

"And he laughed and said, 'Aww Mum, you're a little old granny living in North Queensland. Get over it!' " But will she? Will Emmanuel Goubert, the Love Coach and all the other believers ever get over the lizard monsters, killer vaccines and sinister ex-presidents that move about in their thoughts like squatters in unsecured buildings? Large numbers of them seem to genuinely believe that what they're doing will help bring about a sort of heaven on earth.

My father often used a Biblical quote to invoke his vision of how things would be after he'd helped to save the world from The Plotters: "But they shall sit every man under his vine and under his fig tree; and none shall make them afraid..." (Micah 4:4). The new reality, of course, is that when it comes to making people afraid - of ethnic differences, democratic processes, oncetrusted institutions, even one another - nothing does the job like an online conspiracy epidemic. ï®
