urn:contentItem:5Y57-DXD1-JD34-V555-00000-00MP's speech on bushfire condolence motion2020-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:43ZLexisNexisMP's speech on bushfire condolence motionSteph Cooke

Mr Speaker,

I'd like to join my colleagues from both sides of the house in expressing my condolences to the families and friends of the 25 victims of the bushfires which continue to burn around the State, and thank the Premier for moving this Condolence Motion.

It is entirely appropriate that we mark these tragic bushfires with condolences; in homes in Australia and overseas, families and friends mourn the loss of loved ones who gave everything defending our communities.

We have lost also homes, properties, livestock, fruit trees, beloved horses, pets, and gardens.

To everyone who has experienced loss from these fires my deepest sympathies go out to you all.

As the Member for Cootamundra I speak in support of all who served and volunteered in the Dunns Road Fire which started by lightning strike on the 28th of December 2019, just to the south of Gundagai in my electorate.

This blaze impacted some of our most famous alpine towns and mountain villages, destroying homes, pasture, assets and wilderness areas in Talbingo, Tumbarumba, Green Hills, Wondalga, Willigobung, Courabyra, Tumut, Gilmore Valley, Yarrangobilly, Laurel Hill, Yaven Creek, Batlow, Oberne Creek, Tumbalong, Mount Adrah, Taradale, Mannus, Tooma and many others.

These communities have all been deeply impacted.

The fire ripped through 113,000 hectares of private land, 125,000 hectares of national park, and around 92,000 hectares of State forest.

Fire crews are still on site as they mop up the remnants of the massive combined fire front.

Regional New South Wales is more connected than we sometimes appreciate.

The rapid spread of news on the old Bush Telegraph, social media, or the close ties on a family tree keeps us in touch with others.

Tragedy in one part of the State is felt by loved ones all over.

Whilst hundreds of volunteers and supporters were working on the Dunns Road Fire on New Years Eve, another fire near Wandella took the lives of two incredible and much loved family men.

I want to acknowledge Renee Salway.

A creative soul, Renee worked for me in another life when we were both florists in my business Native Botanical.

Renee loved flowers, but she loved Patrick, horses and farm life more.

This beautiful woman left her job with me in Young to marry Patrick Salway and create a wonderful life and family of their own.

Patrick and his father Robert were killed on the family farm near Wandella.

Patrick was just 29 and Renee is pregnant with their second child.

I want to express my deepest sympathies to her, and all of Robert and Patrick's loved ones.

I also pay tribute to David Harrison of Goulburn, who aged just 47, lost his life defending the property of a friend in Batlow.

His tragic loss during one of the terrifying nights of the Dunns Road Fire is a testament to his character, and I offer his loved ones, family and friends my deepest condolences.

There were many others who risked everything to defend properties and the livelihoods.

The people of Batlow were told their town was 'undefendable' and to expect the worst.

I was at several community meetings, including when this news was delivered.

Even with this information brave locals and Rural Fire Service volunteers, many from my electorate, stayed on to fight the terrifying blaze that tore through the pine plantations and apple orchards that are the livelihood of so many in the region.

In the town of Batlow itself tens of properties were destroyed. It is testament to the incredible work of the RFS and emergency services that the losses were not greater.

I commend Captain Daryl Watkins of Batlow and everyone who defended the town for their remarkable efforts.

The Dunns Road Fire continues to burn on the southern edge of my electorate and at was only officially contained on Sunday afternoon.

It has turned some of our pristine wilderness in to funeral pyres of our unique flora and fauna.

It has taken an enormous effort to contain this beast.

The leadership of RFS Superintendent Roger Orr from Narrandera in the west of my electorate, in the face of this unprecedented challenge was nothing short of extraordinary.

I feel privileged to have met so many volunteers and emergency service workers who showed incredible courage in the face of unprecedented fire conditions. They were joined by colleagues in other organisations including Fire and Rescue NSW, the Forestry Corporation, National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Emergency and Fire Services of the ACT, the Northern Territory, Queensland, Tasmania, Western Australia, the United States and Canada.

I thank you for supporting our local RFS brigades and others from across NSW, many of whom I will mention shortly.

I got to see firsthand the amazing response of those on the front line of firefighting and in supporting roles.

We owe these volunteers and staff an enormous debt of gratitude.

I still marvel at the number of farmers and property owners who left their own homes undefended on severe and catastrophic fire condition days and came together to defend many properties and communities such as Tumbalong at the tip of the Cootamundra Electorate.

These crews included brigades from:

Tumblong Mundarlo Boorowa Gundagai Berremangra Maimuru Wombat Murringo Thuddungra Rugby Boorowa North Boara McMahons Kingsvale Adjungbilly Began Began Stockinbingal Cootamumdra Wallendbeen Frampton Cooneys Creek Brawlin Mt Horeb Coolac Wambanumba Boothenba Rye Park Quambone And let's not forget the 'Mosquito squad' - scores of farmers and their 'slip ons' across the fire ground who worked alongside the RFS and played such a vital part in saving properties.

Apologies if I have missed any of you.

It was a privilege to catch up with so many of you, to make you snack packs, to chat about your brigades and to see you in action.

At its core the RFS is a 'for the community, by the community' organisation, and it must always remain so.

It brings together people from all walks of life, and it's not uncommon to see several generations of the same family on the one tanker.

Fathers, daughters, sons, cousins, siblings, even grandparents and grandchildren.

I witnessed many of these relationships in the crews fighting the Dunns Road Fire, and worked alongside people like Di Lippaitt in the Tumut Fire Control Centre who not only silently carried the worries of the ever changing fire front, but how it would affect her husband and daughter out on tanker crews on the Tarcutta end of the fire, mostly in the Ellerslie Range and Westbrook Road.

Her daughter Courtney also spent time in Fire Comms in Tumut.

Also in Fire Comms were Wilma Cunningham from Griffith and Di Droscher from Batlow, who worked the day we thought Batlow would be lost, and then couldn't return home for several days after.

The fire comms team worked around the clock relaying messages between the Fire Control Centre and brigades on the fire ground, relaying critical information on what the fires were doing, the areas under threat and most importantly where all the firefighting personnel were on the ground.

The welfare checks were a highlight of our work during this uncertain time.

I want to thank them for helping me learn new skills like scribing, and logistics officers Geoff Frowd and Michael Borg for allowing me to be an active part of their team.

These are just some of the people who rarely make the news, but who are an integral part of the firefighting effort.

Seeing the incredible work of this close-knit organisation first hand was a privilege, RFS Superintendent Roger Orr, Inspector Jon Gregory and the teams under their command dealt with difficult terrain, in many places only accessible on foot or by aircraft, conditions permitting, fighting a bushfire that joined with the East Ournie Creek and Green Valley fires to become one of the largest on record.

The success of the RFS fire crews and those that joined them would not have been possible without the help of the Forestry Corporation and the team headed up by regional manager for the Snowy Mountains Dean Anderson.

The Corporation's employees joined firefighting crews, created fire breaks and helped save more than 120,000 hectares of pine trees which are so crucial to the region's economy and the state's timber industry.

The Forestry Corporation, Hume Forests, Hyne Timber, AKD, Visy and others are working more together closely than ever, to process the more than 50,000 hectares of burnt pine trees from the immediate supply area.

I want to note the efforts of the VRA and Search and Rescue in Batlow, Tumut and surrounding regions.

The members of these teams worked tirelessly to help others, and I know at least one member lost his own home while he was saving others.

My thoughts are with you and your family Mick.

To the volunteers of the SES, particularly those from Grenfell, my home town of Temora and my own unit at Junee, I thank you for your supporting efforts.

I want to particularly mention RFS volunteers Donna Martin and her husband Graham, who is the Tumut Group Captain.

They not only worked around the clock like so many others, they found room in their home to put me and my dear friend school teacher Nicole Sanderson, up for day, after day after day.

I will never forget your kindness and hospitality.

Our firefighters, Fire Control Centre and Emergency Operations Centres were fed by an army of volunteers.

Just down the road, the town famous for its dog and tuckerbox saw thousands of volunteers, led by Sue Houstein, making countless meals and snacks for more than a fortnight, feeding firefighters in places like Tumblong and Adelong, and making care packs for those who had lost everything.

This energy was seen everywhere. In Tumut a team of volunteers responded to a call out for help to make meals at 9pm.

Within a few hours we had made 500 sandwiches.

It would be remiss of me not to mention Robert Donges and Wendy Silk of Donges IGA in Young.

Like so many businesses and individuals, they went above and beyond to do their bit, holding a Bushfire Appeal.

Donges IGA appealed for donations of non-perishable food, water, toiletries, baby needs, pet supplies and money for the communities of the South Coast and Snowy Valleys.

To date Donges IGA has distributed $5,000 to the Snowy Valleys recovery centre, $12,000 to the South Coast, $1,700 to Cobargo $4,000 to Eden and $2,000 to Tumbalong in IGA gift cards.

They have also donated much needed water, food and toiletries valued at $20,000 to Tumut and Cobargo.

I was there to meet and unpack the trucks, what an incredible effort.

The town of Young is a small community, and this is not its only fundraising effort.

The Temora Rotary Club also gathered donations from Temora and surrounds.

They managed to collect more than four trailer loads of donations which they took the Tumut Boys Club.

That was a particularly special day because two of the cars were driven by my parents, Marie and Stephen.

In Junee Tearnna Mitchell, Madison Quinn and Jodie Coote, with the assistance of the Locomotive Hotel, organised a fantastic family day and fundraising event.

In Cootamundra, Justyn Smith put out a call for donations of non-perishable food and supplies to take to the evacuation centre at Bermagui.

When they ran out of bags to pack donations in and asked for more, around 2,000 were delivered by the community.

When they realised they didn't have enough bottles to go with baby formula, another 200 were donated.

Less than 7,000 people call Cootamundra home.

Further down the road in Wagga, people came from far and wide to drop off goods, sort donations and help displaced people find a change of clothes, and food for their families.

The volunteers ranged from locals lending a hand, to Yazidi refugees who know first-hand what it is like to have to flee their homes.

The people coming in to these centres were understandably shocked and shaken, but I was told a great story about one who hadn't lost his sense of humour.

After being overcome with emotion at the amount of donations on offer, a man who had evacuated from Batlow stopped crying, smiled and said 'imagine, all this help for us hillbillies'.

We have heard about the mental and emotional toll these fires have caused.

And we must ensure we have adequate mental health support moving forward.

People who would have normally had time to relax and recharge over January have instead given up their holidays to do what they could to help.

There are thousands, including in this chamber, who have come back to work after spending their summer dealing with this crisis.

I want to commend the EOC, FCC and Snowy Valleys Council who kept the residents of towns like Batlow, Tumbarumba and Tumut informed before, during and after the fires came through, and continue to deal with challenges of boil water notices, fallen and dangerous trees and helping property owners keen to get back on site.

Mayor James Hayes, Deputy Mayor John Larter, who is a paramedic himself, and General Manager Matthew Hyde are still working hard for their shire and have an enormous recovery ahead of them.

I also want to note the efforts of the Cootamundra-Gundagai Council, for their work in refilling water bombers, helping to create fire breaks and supporting their colleagues in the Snowy Valleys Council.

My commendations go to Superintendent Bob Noble, Inspectors Steve Radford (who very nearly lost his own home), Peter McClay, Adrian Telfer, John Achinger, Maggie Deal and others for their leadership in the EOC, evacuation centres and all the police who calmly did their jobs in and around fire grounds including Police Officers Mick Jones from Tumbarumba, Amy Zwickl from Batlow and Aaron Kilmurray, also from Batlow, who lost everything in the fire and still caught a looter who had stolen a car.

Their professionalism and courage is something we can all admire.

The efforts of the Murrumbidgee Local Health District are also noteworthy, the MLDH successfully relocated patients and residents of the Batlow Hospital and Aged Care facility to safety in Junee, and the residents from Tumbarumba MPS to facilities in West Wyalong, Temora and Narrandera, all wonderful health facilities in the Cootamundra Electorate.

The staff at these centres rose to the challenge of additional patients and went above and beyond to care for them.

The MLHD successfully returned all these evacuated patients home again.

That mammoth task was done with precision and care, and all staff should be praised for their skill in alleviating what must have been a distressing experience for those frail and vulnerable people.

Now we must head fearlessly in to the recovery phase.

Our National Parks rangers have worked as hard as many of the emergency services, with people like Matt White and Jake Shoard playing a huge role in the Tumut Fire Control Centre.

The task ahead of National Parks to help restore and rejuvenate our wilderness areas is enormous.

I acknowledge all of their efforts so far.

The outstanding work of BlazeAid is now well and truly underway, putting back thousands of kilometres of fencing and helping farmers get back to being the world-beating primary producers they are.

It would be impossible to name every person and every organisation that has gone above and beyond during this crisis.

The long efforts of recovery won't always be front page news.

But those efforts will dictate the future of many communities.

We often say 'regional communities are resilient'.

In the case of these fires, the term fits neatly.

These communities are already looking to the future.

Batlow is determined to hold CiderFest in 2020, thanks to community leader Ray Billings, despite extensive damage to the region's orchards and apple production.

Cider makers like Ralph Wilson want people to remember the best of the region, not the worst.

I hope many of you join me for this fantastic event and in sampling the region's delicious craft cider.

There are months of hard work ahead, I urge you to help in any way you can.

Buy a ticket to Tumbafest, make sure your apples are from Batlow, and stop in at Gundagai on your way there!

There are already people like James Zimmerman leading the Regrow Batlow movement working hard to get their towns back on their feet, and sharing stories about recovery.

Finally I want to thank the Premier Gladys Berejiklian and Deputy Premier John Barilaro, I can think of no better person to coordinate the state's recovery and rebuilding.

I also want to thank the Minister for Emergency Services David Elliot, and the entire Cabinet for their strength in leadership.

Your leadership has helped us all serve our communities better.

I want to acknowledge the work of the Member for Bega Andrew Constance, the Member for South Coast Shelly Hancock, the Member for Wagga Wagga Dr Joe McGirr, MLC Bronnie Taylor, who has been personally touched by this disaster with her property at Yaven Creek being one of the first burnt, and all members who have been so deeply and personally impacted.

I want to thank the Premier for announcing an Inquiry in to these fires, and look forward to us all working together to adopt its recommendations.

We must do everything in our power to protect the lives of our people, our communities and our unique flora and fauna from these sorts of disasters.

This summer was frightening, the fact so many of us are sharing our condolences is a tiny glimpse of the impact on our state and the nation.

May we do everything to ensure it does not happen again.

urn:contentItem:61C2-9JJ1-F031-X376-00000-00The 21st century so far2020-11-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:43ZLexisNexisScience Show2:42 PM AESTThe 21st century so far

Robyn Williams:The Science Show, 'The Big 20', and a program about the first 20 years of this century. Here's Ruth Morgan giving the annual address for the History Council of Victoria.

Ruth Morgan: Today, I want to reflect on futures from the past, that is on the kinds of futures that people in the past expected, hoped or feared. Although some futures past did unfold, it's not necessarily the realisation of these futures that makes them worthy of historical study, rather it's the particular conditions that produced these forecasts, predictions and possibilities, as well as what they set in train and how. That is the historian's concern. The future, after all, is always as much about the past as it is the present.

Robyn Williams: As Professor Ruth Morgan implied, it's fascinating to hear predictions and why we thought the future would unfold in a certain way. When I presented The Science Show number one in 1975, I talked to futurologist Herman Kahn. Australia is fine, I suggested, we've got all those commodities. That's the problem, he replied, you'll remain stuck in the past. So let's go to the past, then the present, starting with some of the forecasting series we did nearly 20 years ago. Here's David Fisher:

David Fisher: We begin with transport. Here's Robyn Williams in the future.

Robyn Williams: This is Perth. It's a lovely winter morning, August 2024, and I could be in any big Australian city. I'm walking down a street in the central business district and as you can hear it's so peaceful. No cars parked anywhere, because that stopped 15 years ago, and the road itself looks different. Smooth, like velvet.

Well, now I want to pick up a car to drive to meet Professor Peter Newman. He was the one who helped revolutionise city transport in this country and around the world about 20 years ago, in 2004. So I'm going to a pick-up spot where there are about 50 tiny two-seater carlets waiting, all shiny and spanking new like the ones you get from car rental firms. So I take out my smart card and wave it past the sensor of this nearest carlet, which can tell two things straight away. First, I'm not pissed, and second, that I've got funds in my account to pay. And I get in and drive off.

Okay, that was 2024. Now we're back in 2004 in one of the main streets, St Georges Terrace in downtown Perth, and the traffic isn't huge but it's heavy enough. Peter Newman, is my vision of what might happen in 20 years' time completely out of the question?

Peter Newman: Well, it's a little bit hard to imagine right now because I'm looking at about 20 four-wheel-drives in the middle of St Georges Terrace, which of course is pretty rugged country to have to drive through. Back to reality and 2020. Historian Ruth Morgan reflects on the big story of 20 years.

Ruth Morgan: The year 2020 was always going to be a tantalising horizon for future thinkers, even its symmetry conjures the clear-sightedness and precision of 20/20 vision, to which policymakers and resource managers always aspire. Twenty years ago, most of southern Australia was still in the grip of the millennium drought. The dry conditions broke records around the nation. Perth's dams were at their lowest since the First World War, and the south-east of the country was on its way to the driest 13-year period since record-keeping began. As the Bureau of Meteorology put it at the time, this was the nation's first climate change drought. That observation came hot on the heels of the third assessment report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which made headlines around the world with its conclusion that: there is new and stronger evidence that most of the global warming observed over the last 50 years is attributable to human activities.

If suburban households become complacent about their household water use, then the drought was a wake-up call. Across the nation, education campaigns and water-saving devices joined water restrictions in an effort to ease pressure on limited urban water supplies. In Melbourne, for instance, the voluntary Target 155 campaign aimed to more than halve the daily water consumption of residents by encouraging shorter showers while imposing strict limits on watering gardens and washing the car.

Brisbane went even further, aiming to reduce residential water consumption to 140 litres of water per person per day. The rainwater tank and greywater recycling became suburban must-haves, offering the means to keep gardens green in trying conditions. As the dam levels fell lower and lower, state governments turned to desalination, with Perth leading the way in 2006, a prospect that was unthinkable just a decade earlier.

Other states took notice, and before long desalination plants were on the drawing board for the Gold Coast, Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide. But, for the most part, by the time those projects were completed, the rains had returned to the east coast and the plants built there were dismissed as white elephants.

Journalist Chris Hammer noticed this change in the weather himself as he reflected in the updated edition of his book on the Murray-Darling Basin in 2010. Browsing through his local bookshop, he'd realised that his book, The River, had somehow migrated from the environment and ecology section where it had stood just six months ago, to a new place on the history shelves. Even so, this record La Niña rainfall that broke the millennium drought did not turn back the clock. A drying trend continued across the south of the continent, particularly in the south-west where winter rains had been in decline since the 1970s, due in part to human induced climate change. Indeed, while Eastern Australia experienced record high levels of rainfall in late 2010 and in 2011, Perth and much of south-western Western Australia experienced record dry weather.

These are just some of the challenges of planning for both climate variability and climate change on a continent of extremes. It's been looking ahead into the future that has been one of the ways in which Australians have long tried to come to terms with this continent of extreme climate variability.

In 2011, the Climate Commission released its first report, declaring that Australia was facing the critical decade. Back then of course the Climate Commission was a federal government body, established under the Gillard government, but it was dissolved under the Abbott government soon after its election in 2013. The decade to 2020, the Climate Commission's report argued, was critical in terms of meeting the 2 degrees Celsius guardrail by curbing emissions of carbon dioxide.

In the decade to 2020, global emissions had to be well on track to reaching zero by 2050 to limit the planet's warming. Taking the temperature on the nation's progress towards this goal in 2017, the Climate Council, the independent body that rose from the ashes of the Climate Commission, declared that Australia was now known as a global climate laggard. Already the concentration of carbon dioxide emissions had tipped over 400 parts per million, higher than at any other time for millions of years, and the planet's temperature was over one degree higher than temperatures before the Industrial Revolution of the late 18th century.

The report warned that the window of opportunity to limit worsening climate impacts is closing, and already extreme climate events were getting worse, pointing not only to bushfires and heatwaves but also to drought and drying across the south of the continent, just as the Garnaut Report of 2008 and countless other scientific studies had predicted. 2019 was the driest year since records began in 1900 and it was the country's warmest year. In fact, all the years since 2013 are among the ten warmest on record for Australia.

The impact of climate change has led to longer, more intense fire seasons, and an increase in the average number of elevated fire weather days as measured by the Forest Fire Danger Index. 2019 saw the highest accumulated index on record. Fires have burned before in Australia, but never like those we saw over the summer. It's cold comfort though, knowing that this disaster was no surprise. After all, the 2008 Garnaut Report warned that fire seasons will start earlier, end slightly later, and generally be more intense. This effect increases over time but should be directly observable by 2020.

In another 10 to 20 years' time, 2019 won't be so unusual. Although this year's emissions might be lower thanks to the Covid lockdowns, and the air might be cleaner, the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere like carbon dioxide continues to rise, and the period 2016 to 2020 looks set to be the warmest five-year period on record.

Unfortunately, a few months of slowing down can't make up for the decades upon decades of greenhouse gas emissions that have accumulated in the atmosphere. History is weighing heavily on the planet's climate future.

Robyn Williams: Associate Professor Ruth Morgan at the ANU, a former ABC Top Five humanities star. Back to our 2024 Dreaming Science Show series and Lynne Malcolm.

The gung ho Australia would really be based on the continuation of fossil fuels, it's burning, it's building, it's buying, it's booming, the cities will become huge and efficient and glamorous and exciting to live in. Meanwhile on The Science Show here's Barry Jones whose book Sleepers, Wake! should have been a roadmap to innovation both in 1982 and 2000.

Barry Jones:Sleepers, Wake!: Technology and the Future of Work, first published in 1982, was an attempt to describe the impact of technological change, especially the information revolution, on employment, industry, education and training. I aspired to make a grand synthesis, linking politics, history, economics, science, technology, education, psychology and information theory.

What Is to Be Done is not an update or a revision - too much has changed since 1982 - but a sequel addressing the massive global changes that have occurred since then. A post-industrial workforce, the digital revolution, universal education to higher education, and the emergence of a 'third age' after retirement were all novel concepts, even after the last revision of the book in 1995. Now we take them for granted, but they did not develop as I had hoped.

There are nearly 6 billion users of the internet, more than 60% of the world's population. Our handheld devices have more capacity than the mainframe computers used in the 1969 Moon landing, giving us instant access to the world's intellectual resources.

As well, the United States, the United Kingdom, and Australia have by far the largest cohort of tertiary-qualified citizens in their history. This ought to provide us with an unparalleled capacity to understand the world's greatest problems - climate change, the refugee crisis, degradation of the environment, poverty, pandemics, the exploitation of women and children, terrorism - with an informed population and inspirational leadership.

However, in the digital age, far from exploring the universal and the long-term, both mainstream and social media emphasise the personal, or the tribal, in the short-term. Opinion is preferenced over evidence, and feeling over rationality, while science and free enquiry are rejected or discounted. Empathy, the common good, and preserving the planet have low priority. The planet, notoriously, has no vote. Homo sapiens has morphed into Homo economicus, because all our politics revolves around production and consumption.

What is sometimes called 'the Enlightenment project' has come under sustained attack in the United States, much of Europe, and, to some extent, Australia. Instead, we see a retreat from reason; the rejection of facts and expertise; the rise of populism, snarling nationalisms, tribalism, and conspiracy theories; a fundamentalist revival and hostility to science; a failure of ethical leadership; deepening corruption of political processes; profound neglect of the climate change imperative; and the triumph of vested interests. All are existential threats to civilisation's advancement and the welfare of humanity here and elsewhere.

The greatest threat to liberal democracy and Enlightenment values has not been external - from ISIS or the Taliban or al-Qaeda, China, Russia, or even pandemics - but internal and self-inflicted. The four horsemen of the apocalypse that threaten humanity are: first, population growth; climate change; pandemics; and finally, racism and state violence. All four are inextricably linked. The pressure on resources, compounded by the threat of climate change, has been a major factor in tribal and racial conflicts over access to water and arable land. Meanwhile, millions of refugees are blamed for seeking security for their families, inequality grows exponentially, pandemics have devastating impacts not only for the aged, but on racial minorities who are stressed by insecurity, leading in turn to violent over-reactions by the custodians of law and order.

Donald Trump's election as president of the United States in 2016 was a turning point in modern history, and he has transformed politics beyond recognition, and he has imitators all over the world.

There has been a striking shift in political allegiances, centred on the 'culture wars'. People in the higher socioeconomic levels are becoming more progressive, eager to embrace change and take risks. Those in the lower levels are more conservative, anxious about change, and risk-averse, seeing themselves as potential victims.

When I began writing What Is to Be Done, the book was to be structured around climate change/global warming and the world's failure to act. Back in 1982, I was well aware of this threat, and can claim to have been the first Australian politician to have grasped its significance. However, I did not discuss it in Sleepers, Wake!.

But as I worked on this manuscript in 2020, new issues kept forcing me to rethink and recalibrate it, and they were all inter-related. The coronavirus pandemic, growing inequality, misogyny, the appeal of fundamentalism, state violence, state secrecy, the environmental stress caused by urbanisation and population growth, and gross increases in xenophobia, racism, and intolerance, culminating in the worldwide Black Lives Matter demonstrations. And the economic and social impact of climate change will exacerbate all these problems.

Australia can be outstanding in confronting crises, such as HIV/AIDS, the Global Financial Crisis, COVID-19, and most natural disasters. But its performance was patchy during the long, horrific bushfire season of 2019-20, and it has been woeful in failing to address climate change and transitioning to a post-carbon economy. COVID-19 demonstrated how well the federation could work, and it remains to be seen if this can be maintained in the post-pandemic era.

The better angels of our nature have been well hidden in our politics, with our part-time parliaments, the absence of serious debate, revolving-door prime ministerships, venality, vindictiveness, mediocrity, secrecy, and the influence of vested interests. Science (medical science excepted) is on the retreat, and the universities are under attack.

Citizens everywhere must engage in the great issues, and work together to master evidence and develop our capacity to define, debate, and decide. Without it, our fellow humans will be staring into an abyss.

Despite all this, we have to be optimistic that we will have the wisdom, courage, and skill to save the planet - and ourselves. It's the only way to go.

And we continue with someone whose life has been entirely this century. Zofia Witowski-Blake first spoke on The Science Show when she was 15. Now, at 19, she is at the University of Melbourne. And here she describes a turning point in her career so far.

Zofia Witowski-Blake: I was 13 years old when I did my first competitive debate. It was in a small classroom at a neighbouring school with two tables set up facing the room for each of the teams to sit behind. I remember thinking that the room looked far too normal for the amount of adrenaline coursing through my body. But the opposing team came in, sat down, and we got ready to start.

They were from a private boys' school and were a year older and a head taller, and all of them wore these crisp red blazers with shiny gold badges. My team, all female and from a public school, wore daggy and baggy puffer jackets.

I was the third speaker for my team, which meant that I was supposed to come up with my speech during the debate by responding to the other side's points. By the first speaker, the fire alarm had gone off, and at the second, someone's phone started ringing. Things were not going to plan. My moment came, I stood up, said, 'As the third speaker I will be rebutting the arguments of the negative team,' looked down at my notes, and started to cry.

Glossophobia is the fear of public speaking, which translates literally to 'tongue dread'. And crying while public speaking is a worst-case scenario. But, thinking the situation could be salvaged by doubling down, I stood up there and kept on trying to speak, keeping everyone's eyes on me while struggling to form sentences, words getting mashed together into a soup. The tongue is made of a conglomeration of eight separate muscles, and on that day, mine were not working together.

This continued for three to four minutes, by the end of which I had made everyone in the room extremely uncomfortable. 'Mortification' comes from the word for death, and after that debate, I felt like I had died of embarrassment. It was physically painful. And while public speaking is the number one fear for many people, my whole life at age 13 felt like pinging from one incident of huge embarrassment to the next, which I think is a pretty common experience.

The pain of embarrassment at that age stems from not having a settled sense of self. There is the idea that one misstep could define your public memory, become what your classmates, teachers, everyone thinks when they look at you. Additionally, when we experience extreme embarrassment, our brains are flooded with adrenaline which acts as a glue for long-term memory. This is why I'm able to recall my debating failure so clearly seven years later, and probably until I die.

Early puberty is a period of immense growth in the brain. Your prefrontal cortex is still being developed, so decision-making is partly delegated to the amygdala, which is associated with emotions, impulses, aggression and instinctive behaviour. Furthermore, the huge amount of synapses, the connections between neurons that are formed when you are an infant are being pared back in a process called synaptic pruning. This is a really important part of brain development that makes the brain more efficient at processing information, and when it doesn't happen, it has been shown to increase the likelihood of conditions like schizophrenia. But when I hear the phrase 'synaptic pruning', it just sounds like a tiny little gardener running around my brain with giant sheers, chopping at neurons.

So, being 13 is like being stuck between being a kid and being an adult, and making mistakes about how to act in both directions. Meanwhile, a huge construction project is taking place in your head and in the rest of your body, making it harder to resist impulses and make decisions. No wonder it's so difficult to figure out what to do, and no wonder it's so painful when you get it wrong.

And that brings me back to debating, because speaking well in public is based on the fact that you're supposed to look completely at ease and in control or, at the very least, like you're not about to cry all over the podium.

So after that first disastrous debate, I could have easily never done another, except for the debate adjudicator who was there that day. He was a university student and his job was to decide on the outcome of the debate and provide feedback for each of the speakers. When he came to me, he said that I should try to concentrate on breathing and slow down. He said that it was okay to take a pause to gather my thoughts. His feedback was kind, and it made me want to try again.

Now, that feeling of terror, of tongue dread, didn't just go away. One time I made the mistake of having a cup of coffee before a public speaking heat, and experienced the curious sensation of simultaneously needing to go to the toilet, throw up, and sprint 500 metres at the same time. Doing a lot of public speaking and doing it badly was a very, very reliable way to experience mortification. But as I did it more and more, that feeling slowly started to lose its power.

In my first debate, the guys on the opposing team seemed to know everything, to be self-assured and in complete control. But it was an illusion and one that I learned how to perform just as well. I got better at speaking convincingly on issues I was just learning about, and I became faster at analysing my opponents' points while under pressure. By year 10 I felt confident enough to draw a mind-map of ideas on a piece of paper during the debate, then go up and speak for seven minutes straight. At the end of that year, I won the best speaker award for the region, competing against students who were a year older.

Debating felt like a safe space for practising to be an adult. I got to have a room full of people paying attention to what I was saying, on a range of different issues I wouldn't have known about otherwise. I was into science, while most topics were based on politics. Having already made a habit of embarrassing myself in public, it made it a lot easier to try new things I also felt completely unqualified for. Say, for instance, speaking on the radio.

Robyn Williams: Zofia Witkowski-Blake, now at the University of Melbourne studying science and Cantonese, and representing one of the major spectacular developments in science this century, the rise and rise of smart young women.

Finally in this review of 'The Big 20', a review of The Carbon Club, a new book by Marian Wilkinson. Here's Nick Rowley, former adviser to Bob Carr and Tony Blair.

Nick Rowley: This time next year we must hope that COP26, the November 2021 UN meeting on climate change, will physically take place at the vast Scottish event campus in Glasgow. I say 'hope' because the meeting should have been taking place now. The facility is currently a temporary COVID hospital, hosting hundreds of beds and respirators.

Much as the COVID pandemic has caused untold pain and suffering around the world, it has done more than suck attention away from the social, environmental and economic threat of global climate change, it has physically replaced an international conference with a hospital.

Never should one expect shards of truth, light and wisdom to come from any international climate conference, but I believe, whether it be virtual or in person, Glasgow has the potential to be every bit as important as the 2015 Paris meeting that led to the Paris Accord.

Ten years prior to Paris, 2005 was the last time that the UK hosted a major meeting on the climate problem. In that year, Tony Blair had made climate change and African development his two key priorities for the G8 meeting at the Scottish golfing resort of Gleneagles. This was the first time that climate change had been presented as a challenge requiring intervention by heads of state. For the then Prime Minister, it was only decisions and leadership by presidents or prime ministers that could affect those of treasuries, energy ministers and international investment. For Blair, leave the required international response solely to negotiators working for environment ministers, and the decisions would not have the force required.

No country is an exemplar of climate policy response, but in the UK the debate regarding how to reduce the risk of global climate change has been largely civil, deliberative and characterised by hard work and leadership from all conservative and progressive prime ministers. Margaret Thatcher's early interventions on the national and international stage, Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's initiation of the seminal Stern Review, and passing the UK Climate Change Act entrenching national carbon budgets in law. Theresa May legislating the national goal of net zero emissions by 2050. And yes, despite all of his populist flourishes and focus on the European question, Boris Johnson's consistent appeal to being on the right side of the climate debate.

This is more than show. A series of political and policy decisions over the past 30 years have provided the continuity and stability required to deliver the investment and innovation essential to reducing emissions at scale. Ten years ago, around 40% of Britain's power came from burning coal. In June this year, the country went more than two months without generating any electricity from it. This is no accident, it has been a dramatic transformation in the energy system, born of scientific rigour and advocacy, political will and policy consistency. Sadly, this is far from the case in Australia.

When I first saw Marian Wilkinson's The Carbon Club on the shelves of a local bookshop, I thought it best to leave it there. Having spent much of the past 20 years working to achieve a more effective response to the global climate problem, the thought of me looking over my shoulder again at the train wreck of Australia's failed national climate policy efforts filled me with dread. Did I really need to consider the dynamics leading to the ill-conceived, incompetently sold, ridiculously technically complex CPRS policy acronym failing to secure the necessary parliamentary support again? What would I achieved by reading about the ways that the men in the shadows orchestrated an undermining of basic climate science through funding and supporting a group of crude but articulate pseudoscientific naysayers attacking world leading scientists and organisations such as the CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology again?

And what of the actors described? Mostly egotistical man, collectively driven by their own political or financial interests, seeking to thwart decisions intended to address a truly wicked problem, understood and explained by some of the most respected scientific, economic and policy minds in the country. What was the point? What more could I learn? We know this teenager's bedroom is a mess, did I really need another tour of the dirty washing, the grey sheets and the piles of apparently precious junk?

But, painful as it was, having read Marian Wilkinson's book, it is only by us looking back and examining this messy, costly, torrid tale of crude politics, incompetence and policy failure that all Australians might come to understand the roots of that failure and how we might embrace a better, cleaner and, yes, richer future.

It is surely a positive characteristic of our democracy that Australia is so well served by a number of brilliant investigative journalists: Kate McClymont at the Sydney Morning Herald uncovering corruption in New South Wales, Sally Neighbour leading multiple investigations for ABC television's Four Corners program, and Marian Wilkinson who, with The Carbon Club, has written a tour de force revealing the ghastly entrails of Australia's climate policy failures. All have shed light on the dark doings and decisions of those looking to pursue private or self-interest at the expense of public value.

Over the more than 400 pages of The Carbon Club, Wilkinson systematically and forensically looks back over the past 20 years of our national failure to face up to the severe risks of climate change and develop a meaningful national policy to address it. From the corridor skills of getting the numbers in Canberra, to the international campaigns funded by fossil fuel interests in Washington, to the failed efforts of Prime Minister Rudd at Copenhagen, Wilkinson periodically brings us back to the effects of an ever hotter, more unstable climate on the Great Barrier Reef. The bad political theatre has consequences. No sooner are there moments where progress seems assured and the balloon will fly and a mixture of political ego, incompetence, overt rent seeking and events intervene to puncture it. Each time we are left with nothing more than a steady hiss as the air goes out of the climate response balloon.

With a few exceptions, most notably those public servants entrusted with developing coherent policy out of the inconsistent cacophony of Australia's toxic climate politics, the players, be they those opposed to meaningful climate response, or those who have tried, however incompetently, to lead, few come out of this story with their reputations enhanced.

Although it may be an easy story to tell and believe, this is no simple tale of the evil of the fossil fuel industry and those doing its bidding in a club triumphing over the forces of good. Much as former Prime Minister Kevin Rudd tried, his efforts on climate policy were constrained by his intellectual vanity and political ineptitude. There is no alternative history and all political leaders have their strengths and weaknesses, but the early sloth of his administration, producing endless analysis and reports, littered with numbers and acronyms and targets that few understood and no one could relate to, led to confusion and no command of the political agenda.

The rhetoric is not hard. The defining challenge of our generation and one of the greatest moral, economic and environmental challenges of our age at the UN Bali conference coming just two weeks after securing government was then addressed by a policy process of seemingly endless document production leading to an approach introduced at the wrong time in the wrong way, using a language of weak targets, timetables and perverse subsidies that few understood and opponents could easily attack.

Rather than lead and face up to the hard decisions and trade-offs required to achieve progress, Rudd attempted to manage Australia's position. And when the going got tough post-Copenhagen, he froze. In presenting this story, Wilkinson allows the reader to observe and reach their own conclusions. As each page turns, the more one realises that The Carbon Club has a wide spectrum of members. Some, previously describing themselves during the Howard years as the Greenhouse Mafia, ruthlessly protect their interests and seek to ensure that ambitious Liberal and Labor Party politicians understand the importance of protecting the fossil fuel economy. Others are part of a wider group, those in either of the major parties who abstractly accept the science on climate change but aren't bold enough to shape rather than respond to the prevailing politics.

Nowhere is this better illustrated than the current Labor opposition's 'clarity' on the straightforward what question of committing to a net zero target by 2050, while remaining supportive of Prime Minister Morrison's gas lead recovery and unable to state a position on no new coal-fired power stations in Australia. Net zero with new coal-fired power stations is like committing to a goal of competing in the Olympics on a training regime involving the sofa, burgers, beer and chocolate cake. Not only impossible, but incoherent, confused and confusing to anyone concerned about Australia's future climate and economic security.

Yet none of this is easy. With the first policy including the purpose of reducing emissions being in California in the early 1990s, climate policy remains immature. But much like a marriage, deciding to argue for, develop and implement policies that reduce the risks of climate change is a strategic choice. Not sparkling wine and red roses every day, occasional tension, some annoying habits, but ultimately a decision which provides a mutually reinforcing positive structure to one's life. It is a choice that the UK hosts for COP26 made years ago, a choice that President Xi of China made clear in his speech to the UN General Assembly in September, and one that the new Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga announced in his first policy speech to the Japanese parliament last month. Both governments of our major trading partners have committed to net zero by 2050 or 2060 and are developing the policies to achieve it.

And with a new Biden presidency in the United States seeking to demonstrate positive global leadership, Glasgow has the potential to be a significant step forward in further legitimising and supporting the national, state and local actions required to respond effectively to global climate change. Australia, continuing to maintain its short-sighted, parochial and self-defeating position, self-servingly supported by the Carbon Club for so long, now exposes our economy to significant risk.

Like the coronavirus, climate change respects no boundaries. Emissions from Ohio affects the climate in Jakarta. And policies elsewhere also serve to affect decisions here. It might just be that the lack of leadership in Canberra will not end up being as consequential as it has been. Ultimately it may be the policy decisions of Australia's major trading partners, made in Glasgow and elsewhere, that will have more effect than the work of the Carbon Club and the toxic climate politics described so ably by Marian Wilkinson.

Robyn Williams: And her book, yes, The Carbon Club, was reviewed by Nick Rowley, former adviser to Bob Carr and in 10 Downing Street to Prime Minister Tony Blair. Do keep listening this week to 'The Big 20: Our century so far', on RN.

This article deals with discourses of intimate partner violence and is based on interviews with professionals who meet violent men. The professionals emphasized the importance of men taking unreserved responsibility for their violent behavior. Intimate partner violence was viewed not only as “power and control” but as the result of complex situations and interplays. The discourses presented an ambivalent explanation of violent men as both ordinary and deviant. They were understood as having a strained background, but to be rather ordinary, often functioning well at work and in society. Yet, they have nonstandard views of women, act deviant in their communication and interplay with others, and cannot cope with certain situations in intimate relationships. Based on the interviews, men inclined to partner violence may be generalized as those who: attack immediately, explode unexpectedly, or ultimately become aggressive. The discussion challenges unreflected discourses as means for change when counteracting violence.
