Many thanks to the professionals for their open and helpful attitude and also special thanks to Bo Nilsson, head of the Department of Culture and Media, Faculty of Art, Umeå University, for his use- ful analytical comments. Correspondence and requests for reprints should be sent to Kerstin Edin, Epidemiology, Department of Public Health and Clinical Medicine, Umeå University, SE-901 85 Umeå, Sweden; tel: +46 (0) 90 785 13 33; fax: +46 (0) 90 13 89 77; e-mail: kerstin.edin@epiph.umu .se; Web site: www.umu.se/ phmed/epidemi 226 2002). Even if men are typically identified as being responsible for most intimate partner violence (Heise & Garcia-Moreno, 2002; Tjaden & Thoennes, 2000), there are studies that indicate that women can be as vio- lent as men in a relationship (Straus, 1999). Men's violence against women, however, has different causes and much more serious consequences than that of women against men (Cascardi, Langhinrichsen, & Vivian, 1992; Lawson, 2003; Straus, 1999; Zlotnick, Kohn, Peterson, & Pearlstein, 1998). This article deals with male violence—the focus of the programs repre- sented by the interviewed professionals. Many elements are involved when violence takes place in a relationship. Even if intimate partner violence can largely be explained in terms of gender orders and power structures, it is multifaceted and cannot easily be explained without also considering the complexity of the interaction between individual, contextual, and sociocultural factors (Firestone, Harris, & Vega, 2003; Heise, 1998). Nor are the solutions to intimate partner vio- lence simple and, in the long term, major efforts will be required to contin- ually change social structures, norms, and strategies. Yet, in the short term, at least according to a number of opinions, individuals who perpetrate inti- mate partner violence need to be confronted in efficient programs (Gelles, 2000). The efficacy of treatment programs for male offenders has, however, frequently been called into question, inviting further research and develop- ment (Babcock, Green, & Robie, 2004; Gelles, 2000). Hence, to counteract intimate partner violence more effectively we certainly need a better and more specific understanding of how the problem is multifaceted. Intervention programs for men inclined to violence start out from curricula and are usually led by professionals by means of dialogues and group con- versations with the men aimed at changing their attitudes and behaviors. These professional discourses may come into play to a greater or lesser extent and are doubtless the result of a synthesis of the professionals' own preconceived ideas influenced by the media and public opinion, expert knowledge and experience, and insights gained from meeting men inclined to violence. Additionally, the standpoints taken do not simply correspond to the professionals as individuals but, as authorities, they have knowledge and power and are deemed to be or become the possessors of the truth (Hall, 2001). In view of this, it seems reasonable that not only the syllabus but also the professionals themselves exert an important influence on men in the intervention programs for those men inclined to violence. However, this dis- cursive influence is to date a little-known area and this article aims to con- tribute knowledge about professional discourses related to the underlying 227 causes of intimate partner violence. The results will be discussed by way of “attribution theory” (AT; Augoustinos & Walker, 1995) with a focus on gender, because ideas about the complex construction and reconstruction of gender identities need to be encompassed and challenged when discussing the causes of attitudes and behaviors in men inclined to violence (Hearn, 1998; Heise, 1998). Objective The objective of this article was to explore discourses of intimate part- ner violence and causal attribution in professionals working with violent men, with a special focus on gender issues. The Theoretical Framework “Constructionism” views knowledge as a varying collective construct that is shaped, shared, and expressed in the daily interactions between people, individually and collectively, in a historically and culturally vary- ing reality (Burr, 2003). “Discourse” is one way to embrace such a plural- ity of social contexts that are complex, conflicting, and change with time and place. To analyze a discourse is thus to construct a joint understanding through interpretation; this involves power and necessarily results not in complete but in only partial knowledge (Hall, 2001; Taylor, 2001). Gender is constructed in and by discourses that mainly position men as superior to women, and is normative but not consistent because it is socio- culturally reproduced and transformed. However, the change is usually very slow because it involves power and requires interactions and negotiations (Connell, 1995; Edley, 2001; Kimmel, 1987). To focus on gender as a nor- mative discourse implies opening up for change, as discourses are not sta- tic constructs but are changeable in interactions with others (Burr, 2003; Dahlgren, Emmelin, & Winkvist, 2004). Discourses of causal attributions are constructed from many feelings, shared ideas, and social concepts and are often created spontaneously when negative or unexpected events occur. AT seeks to understand the way people attribute causes to their own and others' behavior; how and why they do this and the conditions under which they do and do not attribute. However, AT not only reveals regularities but also reasons for limitations and biases in how people make or alter causal attributions (Augoustinos & Walker, 1995). 228 Methods Qualitative methods were chosen because the intention of the study was to explore and deepen the understanding of a very complex subject area. Data collection and analyses were informed by grounded theory and dis- course analysis—methods that were found to be complementary (Dahlgren et al., 2004; Starrin, Dahlgren, Larsson, & Styrborn, 1997; Wheterell, Taylor, & Yates, 2001a, 2001b). Participants and Settings The sample was purposely chosen to find a variety of professionals who men inclined to violence meet when attending diverse intervention programs in Sweden, excluding, however, prison divisions for sexual offenders, psychi- atric care, and forensic care. This was done intentionally to keep the study within realistic bounds and restricted to programs where the clients were con- sidered unlikely to be explicitly identified as being psychopathological. The interviews were carried out at four institutions with different pro- grams and locations: two at a crisis center for men (where on admission 25% to 30% avowed being inclined to violence but declared various life crises; all men were admitted voluntarily and mostly had no police report); three at a joint center for families within the probation service (where all the men had been violent against women and the majority had a police report); and finally three interviews at two prisons (running different crime- prevention programs for men). Hence, it follows that these clients ranged from those who had used rather mild violence to others who had used very severe violence. One program was clearly based on family systems theory, whereas the other three seemed to mix a variety of theoretical approaches that, in practice, were more or less in agreement with cognitive behavioral therapy and referred to programs such as “Alternatives to Violence” in Norway (Råkil, 2002; Rothman, Butchart, & Cerdá, 2003). The six male and two female informants had different professions (psy- chologists, social workers, and prison officers) and three of them were also certified therapists. The professionals had wide experience from a variety of work such as within social services, family counseling, psychiatry, and the prison establishment. Information about a client's violence was given to the professionals largely by the men themselves, but was also obtained from crime reports, if accessible, and some professionals occasionally listened to the women's side of the stories to gain a more balanced understanding. How- ever, two interviewees obviously had a different and more limited experience 229 of the interview objectives, since compared to the others who had open dia- logues with the men involving confrontation and uncompromisingly taking responsibility for violent behavior, they were required to strictly follow a curriculum allowing no space for free discussions within the group. The interviews aimed to discover discourses underlying the viewpoints presented by the professionals. Every interview was thus regarded as mir- roring larger structures and not just as giving words to individual positions (Connell, 1995). Interviews The qualitative research interviews were carried out by the first author (KE) between May 2002 and June 2003. Each session started with an open chat, followed by a recorded interview lasting approximately 2 hours. A mind map was used as a guide in the interviews, covering four broad subject areas: the professionals' experience and knowledge in general and regarding violence related to pregnancy, childbirth, and parenthood; about the meanings and definitions of violence; about opinions and attitudes regarding counteracting or triggering sources of violence; and finally ideas about intervention. Although detailed open-ended questions were available as a backup, the inquiries did not have a fixed format and individual ques- tions could be dropped and new ones introduced as indicated by the situa- tion (Kvale, 1996; Starrin et al., 1997). As soon as possible after each interview the recorded disc was transcribed verbatim (by KE) with small revisions to safeguard the informant's anonymity and minor corrections to improve comprehension. Regarding the four main subject areas (see above), the interviews resulted in very rich data (cf. Edin, Dahlgren, Högberg, & Lalos, in press) as well as opening up many related wide-ranging lines of rea- soning, and the results currently presented are a selection (of all those obtained) that meet the objective of this article. Analyses The analyses were performed by the first writer (KE) in cooperation with one of the other authors (LD). Memos and preliminary analyses were completed for each interview (Starrin et al., 1997). During the intial analysis, particular words and clauses were represented as codes and categories, leading gradually to the appearance of certain patterns as well as the identification of outlines and discursive elements (Dahlgren et al., 2004). Summaries were written for each interview and finally all notes were compared to seek agreements and 230 disagreements to emerging assumptions. To exclude misunderstandings, the results were constantly compared with earlier analyses and the original data. Ethics The study was approved by the local Ethics Committee at the Faculty of Medicine, Umeå University, Sweden. Findings The findings are presented with the intention to give a broad picture of the professional discourses, and generally not to speak for each and every professional individually. When the words deviant and normal are used in the findings this does not refer to any categorization but rather represents how it was understood within the professional discourses. The results in the text are structured in accordance with Figure 1 and consist of four themes (main headings) with a number of underlying aspects (subheadings), fol- lowed by descriptive categories. The first three themes are dimensions of the professional discourse where “violent men's responsibility” is superior and placed at the top of the figure as a guiding principle in the programs that largely focused on the misdeeds and the acts of violence (cf. Edin et al., in press). The fourth theme, “masculinity discourses of violent men,” illustrates three generalized characteristics in violent men, as derived from the interviews with the professionals. Quotations are displayed, after care- ful translation from Swedish into English. Violent Men's Responsibility The programs focused on male violence, and the professionals thought it was excellent that men's violence towards women had become visible in society. Some professionals, however, questioned why women's violence against men was considered to be nonexistent and that talking about it was inappropriate for political or ideological reasons. All in all, the profession- als had open and positive attitudes and were generally very self-critical with a wish to develop the programs they were representing. The professionals all agreed on the importance of making men respon- sible for their own violent behavior, regardless of the circumstances. Although the men tended to excuse themselves, especially when they first joined the programs, they were allowed neither room for excuses nor to 231 Figure 1 Professional Discourses of Intimate Male Partner Violence blame anyone other than themselves. Some of the professionals neverthe- less brought up examples of exceptionally extreme situations with, for example, insult, where refraining from violence would have been very demanding and difficult. Consider Themselves as Innocent The professionals said that men tend to diminish what has happened, seem not to fully understand the consequences of their violent behavior, 232 and are thus able to justify themselves (such as quoted and commented on below) and even portray themselves as victims. “I am not the person who is the abuser, if that is what you now believe, but in fact it was like this” . . . so you are in a story that still touches very little on guilt and responsibility. According to the professionals, men do not seem to lack the standard norms, such as the taboo on hitting a woman, and after an act of violence men usually express regret for their own behavior. However, violent men often blame someone else, such as the woman or the circumstances in which the violence had occurred, and many of men serving sentences often consider themselves innocent. Men for instance might claim that women cheated on them or offended them emotionally or explain that they had both been fight- ing or that they had reacted to their partner hitting them first or else she was furious, hysterical, and acted badly so he was forced to keep a firm hold on her and to grapple and beat her. Ordinary Men with Deviant Behavior In the interviews it was mentioned that severe and sexual violence and violence during pregnancy are probably more commonly committed by men with various kinds of personality disorders and drug-addiction prob- lems. Yet, the majority of men inclined to violence seem to function well in most cases and are considered to be normal at work and in society. Nevertheless, as described by the professionals, in certain situations violent men act deviant in interplay with others; they have difficulties using emo- tional expressions and typically have a poor ability to communicate in inti- mate relationships. Thus, even though the professionals claimed that violent men are quite ordinary and that practically any man could transgress the limits and use violence, such behavior was never considered normal. . . . then he might be a physician or a politician or such . . . you can find such men in every stratum of society, but that doesn't mean it is a normal phenomenon . . . Violent Men's Interplay Deviant View of Women According to the professionals, it does not seem unusual that men see women more or less as objects and then generalize women into extremes 233 such as “the whore or the Madonna.” However, men inclined to violence appeared to have a deviant view of women compared to other men, as well as ideal images of females with no firm connection to reality. The starting point of violence was seen by the professionals as somehow linked to a dis- contentment within the relationship, quite often related to the man's very high expectations and overly romantic beliefs regarding his partner and their relationship. Men overly adore women as “princesses” and think highly of them; they are beautiful, mysterious, and always understanding and responsible. All this is of course untenable in the long run and, as emerged in the interviews, sooner or later the ambience will disappear and the feelings of love and devotion may become negative. Deviant Language The way people communicate was viewed as particularly important by the professionals. Negative language will move things from bad to worse while the norms are modified step-by-step until a limit is passed and phys- ical violence erupts. As was particularly pointed out by one of the respon- dents, being ironical and sarcastic in everyday language is neither sound nor good and implies criticism that actually denigrates people. To be ironi- cal is to be in power because the associated preferential right of interpreta- tion ensures insecurity in the one subjected to it. According to the interviews, negative language was described as a kind of defense that stems from not being able to cope with a particular situation. . . . when it comes to their act of violence, it starts with “you goddamned hag” or “slut” and then progresses to “fucking whore” and in the next place “you bloody cunt” and subsequently escalates and becomes more and more vilify- ing until it quite soon descends into violence . . . Deviant Interaction It came up in the interviews that men inclined to violence seem to act deviant in their interplay with others. The professionals considered men in general to have fewer close friends than women but also that it looks as if violent men have an even smaller circle of friends and often live in their own world. One of the professionals at a prison had made observations from dia- logues with clients and concluded that violent men and criminals in general seemed to have a distorted and twisted understanding of conversations. They tended to interpret the meaning of words and sentences somewhat dif- ferently from others and therefore often misunderstood them or did not 234 understand at all, and for this reason became uncertain in conversations with others. Violent Men's Aggression Respond to Fear and Threat As pointed out by the professionals, men's aggression and violence can largely be explained as responses to the partner's position that resulted in a variety of reactions in the men emanating from feelings of fear and threat and very often associated with jealousy. Even if “power and control” was used by the interviewees to explain intimate partner violence, apart from one who deemed it to be just clichéd thinking that omits the complexity, it was not what the professionals generally met in their close contacts with men inclined to violence. The respondents reported a much more multifac- eted picture of violent men as commonly displaying themselves as threat- ened and afraid of being a “nobody”; in short, the opposite of feeling strong. The men lack self-confidence and feel insecure, unloved, depen- dent, inferior, unsuccessful, worthless, incapable, and inadequate (cf. Edin et al., in press). In the interviews it was said that as a result men tend to frighten their partners to subordinate them and to achieve power. Threat is experienced in proportion to the amount of fear and is, accordingly, a trig- ger for aggression and violence. According to the professionals, men might hold back aggressiveness out of worry about the consequences if they lose control of their aggression. However, if men do not dare to express their feelings of fear, weakness, and insecurity, these may build up and place them at risk at a later stage of fly- ing into a fit of rage that could be very dangerous. Learned Behavior The professionals described aggressiveness as apparently the only emo- tional expression accepted without challenge as part of the traditional male role. When men's security is disturbed they feel vulnerable, frightened, and threatened and then aggression might be the most familiar and best-known behavior to resort to. As was brought up in the interviews, men sometimes behave with the primitivism of small boys or in the same way as they have seen their own parents act, that is solving conflicts in such abnormal ways as by using both verbal and physical violence. The traditional male role was recurrently mentioned in the interviews as a major underlying cause of partner violence and even, if it is questioned, the messages from society are still ambiguous. According to the interviews, 235 it is obvious that the traditional, profitable, and competitive man is still in demand and that men have to hold back their humanity and empathy as these are not compatible with competition. The respondents suggested that when the traditional male role is counter- acted it may also lead to conflicts and violence because the demands for equal- ity put strains on the relationship and throw the roles into confusion for both men and women. Men who want a change think it is hard to find good role models to copy and many have negative experiences from their own fathers. Thus, as came up in the interviews, overall, men nowadays were understood to be more insecure in their roles and more dependent on women, often feel- ing lost and uncertain about what women in fact want and expect from them as men. The risk of violence increases if a man relates to a woman in terms of being guided by her, relying on her, and not standing up for himself. . . . because you have no one to take as a model, so in the relation men become too much like weathercocks in relation to a woman regarding what she thinks and believes; that also creates an increased sense of not being responsible, that “it doesn't depend on me, I am directed by others” and that also increases the risk of violence . . . Losing One's Head According to the interviews, the act of violence at the moment it occurs could be experienced as a sudden feeling of losing one's head. This feeling might happen in response to threatening and stressful events; alcohol is sometimes involved. Finally, the whole situation is just too much and men might lose their temper and give free rein to their impulses. It is almost a sense of “if I give rein to this it will start a forest fire.” As described by the professionals, all of a sudden men get a sense of madness like a lost moment, a total breakdown where they lose control and do not know what they are doing. This goes from bad to worse, as if some- one else takes control or it is like being on a sudden downhill slope and they feel as if they can neither escape nor cope with the situation nor else stop it. According to the respondents, after such a violent outburst they may become frightened of themselves and are subsequently unable to under- stand or defend their own strange aggressive behavior. . . . then it is something where the system is not sufficient; there's a leakage in the system or a weak spot and that is what we plan to look at . . . and that might be all kind of things. 236 As said in the interviews, most men inclined to violence can, on the face of it, appear quite normal but sometimes act as if they have a weakness, as if they are unfinished or incomplete as people and that something is missing. Violent men see no other way of acting and also lack the ability or willpower to stop their violent impulses. Most men, however, despite their uncontrolled feelings of losing their heads and of the situations being unmanageable, are able to cal- culate and to exert control. For example, according to the interviews, they often direct the violence to spots with the specific intention to hurt and to parts of the victim's body that afterwards are invisible for those around. Moreover, in many of those situations that trigger outbursts of violence, if other people are present, men inclined to violence might even be able to fully control them- selves so as to avoid or postpone the violence. . . . and if they are observed they are able to avoid violence, they themselves actually have full control. Masculinity Discourses of Violent Men In interviewing the professionals, various masculinity discourses of vio- lent men appeared and three generalized characteristics (sociologically, “ideal types”) were found (see Figure 1). The three portrayals are simplifi- cations of men's characteristics and were given metaphorical names that match their attributes. The masculinity discourses might overlap and can all be present in one person while, in fact, they may not be found in a more complex reality. Although the “pressure cooker” was interpreted from a variety of data, the other two stylized characters—“he-man” and “super partner”—originated from one professional's own practical experience but seemed to be fairly congruent with the other professionals' descriptions. It seems to me that we have two categories of violent men. No, we certainly have more, but roughly anyway. But there are two ways of responding to threat and the one is to persuade, so to speak, and the other to attack. “He-Man”—Attacking Man—Immediate Aggression The “he-man” was described as the traditional male being a caricature of a real man working at a man's job (such as repair work, chopping wood, and hunting). The “he-man” was expected to be more common in the coun- tryside than in urban areas. This authoritarian man was portrayed in the interviews as the head of the family and if he is threatened he defends him- self and attacks aggressively and immediately. 237 “Pressure Cooker”—Exploding Man—Sudden Aggression The professionals described one type of violent man as a “pressure cooker” who has learned to keep silent and to keep a distance from emo- tional expressions such as fear, weakness, and insecurity. Men suppress their own feelings and deny aggressiveness because they are afraid of its results, and these feelings may build up and later put them at risk of an out- burst. According to the professionals, if such a man lets his emotions show it gives free rein to aggressiveness that gets worse and worse; he may sud- denly go totally mad, and the exploding man is a fact. “Super Partner”—Persuading Man—Ultimately Aggressive The “super partner” was portrayed as someone who did everything to meet and please his woman; was always willing to help with cleaning, fixing things at home, and taking care of the children. From his own viewpoint, he feels unloved and this represents a threat to him, he tries to persuade her with kind- ness but does not succeed, because whatever the “super partner” does she is still never satisfied and still does not love him. As it was described, the woman might either run off or the situation will finally drive him to despair; he runs out of steam and gets angry, furious, or violent. Discussion In the discourses of professionals working with men inclined to vio- lence, the unconditional responsibility of men for their own violent behav- ior was emphasized. Intimate partner violence was not viewed simply as a result of “power and control” but of a very complex situation and interplay. The professional discourses included ambivalence, because they retained an explanation of violent men as both ordinary and deviant. As came up in the interviews, violent men are for the most part like most men but yet something seemed to be missing and this was revealed in certain situations, such as when they attacked with aggression in interplay as in intimate rela- tionships. But before expanding into a discussion, the trustworthiness of the study needs to be considered. Trustworthiness The interviews were dialogues that, despite the specific themes, had dif- ferent and changing positions (such as gender, age, status, knowledge, and 238 power) that certainly influenced the pre-understanding and construction of the discourse during and between the interviews (Davies & Harré, 2001). Moreover, the study only reports on the professional discourses from the current and specific interview dialogues and not when standing face to face with violent men or others. Only two out of the eight interviewed professionals were women; how- ever, they were not underrepresented in view of the fact that most of the professionals at the four institutions involved in this interview study were men. No obvious diversity was evident between the responses of men and women in the interviews. Gender could in practice still be a very important aspect when meeting the male clients and planning programs. When interviewing the eight professionals it became apparent that their experience came from quite different sets of clients and programs. Even if the sample was intended to include professionals working with men not explicitly identified as being psychopathological, it was still possible that some of their clients had personality or even psychiatric disorders. However, they were still one among others in the variety of programs com- monly offered for men inclined to violence (in Sweden). In addition, sev- eral other different underlying factors to the professionals' understanding of men's violence and hence constructing their discourses about men's inti- mate partner violence are not covered by this study. This was a small interview study, however each interview was consid- ered a keyhole through which wider discourses could be glimpsed (Connell, 1995). Moreover, it is feasible to compare the study with other relevant research (Dahlgren et al., 2004). After eight interviews it was agreed that data had reached redundancy in terms of the purpose of the study (Kvale, 1996). Accordingly, the findings are probably transferable to other comparable programs for violent men, but could rather and probably more importantly start up fruitful discussions about professional discourses and their impact on violent men. Causal Attribution and Gender The efficacy of programs for male offenders has been questioned and new concepts have been requested (Babcock et al., 2004; Dankwort, 1994; Fox, 1999; Gelles, 2000). Professional discourses, because of their author- ity and expert status, have an important value and power (Hall, 2001). Accordingly, the professionals' discourses of causal attribution are relevant to the framing of intervention programs and when standing face to face with violent men. What follows below is a discussion concerning possible 239 influences on the professional discourses of causal attribution based on AT (see the section “Theoretical Framework”) as well as a discussion focusing on masculinity. The intention is not to provide fixed solutions but to chal- lenge the professional discourses by raising new questions and ideas that could make a difference regarding the target of changing violent men's behaviors and attitudes. Commonly, actors (in this study, the offenders) relate their actions to the concrete situation and circumstances (external attribution) whereas the observers (here the professionals) are more abstract and find the causes in the actors' personalities (internal attribution; Augoustinos & Walker, 1995). According to what was said in the interviews, violent men's external attribution was actively counteracted by the professionals in making them individually confront and accept responsibility for their violent behavior. Though there seems no reason to abandon that standpoint, there is a risk that such discourses might close the door to deeper dialogues about emo- tions and about what in fact happened as well as a further elaboration of underlying models and social forces in society. Moreover, one might want to explore the complexity in the construction of men's gender identities and examine what formed them as men inclined to violence (Hearn, 1998; Heise, 1998). Men usually disconnect violence from other practices, but to fully understand the sources of violence, men need not just to be confronted with their violent acts but with the gendered performance of daily interplay and negotiations, especially as intimate partners and parents (Hearn, 1998). If this is not done, such narrow discourses might risk reinforcing and repro- ducing stereotypical masculinity discourses and hence support the violence (Hearn, 1998). Attribution might be influenced by personal and emotional reasons and may change over time and vary with age, class, status, various political opinions, culture, etc. Attribution is often made to serve one's own purposes (self-serving bias) and has a tendency to overestimate the commonality of one's own attribution. If something seems different or stands out in attribu- tion, this will be stated as being less significant when formulating one's own opinions. Moreover, there is a tendency to attribute behavior to a sin- gle rather than to multiple causes and the more one cause is favored as the explanation for a particular behavior the less likely the others are to be used (Augoustinos & Walker, 1995). The professionals in this study might have made simplifications in sorting out a few common and accepted explana- tions just through an unconscious or convenient attribution to fit their own professional theories. They may also, in the interviews, have positioned themselves in relation to the interviewer as being someone with a certain 240 stance. There are other possible explanations such as the fear of being an embarrassment to colleagues, employers, creators of public opinion, etc. and thus finding themselves in an untenable position as a professional. On the other hand, they presented a rather multifaceted and heterogeneous dis- course about violent men (cf. Figure 1) quite concordant with what has been presented in research (cf. Cavanaugh & Gelles, 2005; Holtzworth- Munroe & Meehan, 2004; Holtzworth-Munroe & Stuart, 1994). Such knowledge might possibly form, or at least exert an influence on, the pro- fessionals' construction of reality. The attribution regarding the actor's character is likely to be as negative as the observed behavior and if the actor's behavior differs from one's own behavior there is a tendency to attribute it to the deviances (Augoustinos & Walker, 1995). For violent men there might be no extenuating excuses and hence they should be regarded with much suspicion. The professionals in this study described violent men as both ordinary and deviant, for example in their views of women, interaction, and language, as well as in daily inter- play, especially in close and intimate relationships. In many ways, the pro- fessional discourses seemed to construct and/or reproduce stereotypes of such men as being loners, “pressure cookers”, macho, unable to express feelings, and all in all as being insufficient (cf. Dankwort, 1994). However, apart from the violent behavior, most of the characteristics of violent men could be viewed as quite familiar and ordinary behavior for many and not as belonging only to violent men. In agreement with both theories about attribution and masculinity, people (such as the professionals) prefer to latch on to deviances when it comes to destructive behavior, maybe as a means of keeping a distance and confirming their own normality by alien- ating themselves from preferably lower status groups and from problematic masculinities (such as that of violent men; Augoustinos & Walker, 1995; Kimmel, 1996). From this it follows that the deviant characteristics might then have been overstated as a way of producing normality and possibly of drawing a more visible line between normal and deviant because that line might be very vague. Moreover, to have reasonable motives for running programs for men inclined to violence (and not simply for all men), one probably needs to agree on some kind of deviancy and need for correction, at least to some extent (Fox, 1999). But the one does not exclude the other and the deviant behaviors could have been understated to support and follow the prevailing and politically correct public opinion in Sweden. How- ever, the professionals might diplomatically (self-serving bias) have posi- tioned themselves between these two standpoints; namely, violent men are like any other person (normal) but also with unacceptable behavior and in need of correction (deviant). 241 Masculinity is a constructed concept and the dominant and exaggerated forms of masculinities are wholly embodied in very few real men (Connell, 1995) but are maintained and reproduced by superiority and culture as reflected in the media, movies, music, etc. (Hearn, 1998). Men may act according to the inflated forms in certain situations and interactions, but because these are not static and not completely legitimate they need to be defended and strengthened by various means, such as the use of persuasion, pressure, and even violence (Connell, 1995; Hearn, 1998). However, neither deep-rooted gender belief nor causal attribution is static. Alteration can happen for many different reasons, such as the discovery of new understanding or new-found facts (Augoustinos & Walker, 1995; Edley, 2001; Kimmel, 1987). The instability is a challenge for the possibility of change regarding the professional discourse of causal attribu- tion and a deeper understanding of gender constructions in men. If the mas- culinities are to be transformed one might need to go back to the basis of the constructs and discover the contradictions and meanings in the gendered prac- tices and interplay such as occur in parenthood as well as in intimate relation- ships and sexuality (Hearn, 1998, 2000). Accordingly, one practicable method to be used in the programs for violent men could be to analyze critically the everyday and ordinary masculinities as practiced in negotiation and renegotiation by men towards women and children as well as other men (Hearn, 2000). One cannot separate the violent behavior from the discourse because they are connected (Hearn, 1998). If on the one hand men are invited to be open but on the other are told that their thoughts are incor- rect, in turning them back on what they bring up, the dialogues may become con- trolled, resulting in coercive and repressive professional discourses (Fox, 1999). If men's refusal to go along with the professionals' way of thinking is interpreted as denial, it may reinforce the dichotomy between evil and good and paint real- ity in just Black and White (ibid.). Instead, the disagreement between the men's and the professionals' discourses could be viewed as a source of discovery and be used as a powerful tool to discover the underlying causes of profound attitudes and behavior (ibid.). It is a challenge to request further research and development where professionals dare to tackle new ways when counteracting intimate partner violence (cf. Edin et al., in press). One possibility could be to apply scientific assumptions using methods where the emphasis is on discourse, as a way to replace or perhaps complement ongoing programs. Conclusion The discourses of causal attribution in the professionals interviewed could be summarized as “ordinary and deviant” because that mirrors quite 242 well the contradictions and complexities of intimate partner violence. In parallel to general and common mainstream beliefs, they expressed their own insights and vacillated between different explanations and viewed vio- lent men as being like any other men but with a deviant manly behavior. Masculinity is constructed in relation to femininity and in negotiated inter- actions and interplay and the depicted forms and concepts of masculinity need to be challenged. Much could be started on an individual level (as in the programs for violent men) by the professionals' confronting and oppos- ing men's discourses and usual everyday gender practices in, for instance, showing them power structures with examples from their own real and everyday life (Dankwort, 1994; Hearn, 2000). As the professionals are authorities, they could be a great asset as possible innovators working against current streams and hence contributing to various social and cul- tural processes that set new agendas. Essential Energy Bushfire Update - 1.00pm Monday 13 January 2020

A large contingent of Essential Energy crews and contractors from across NSW worked through the weekend to make repairs to the damaged electrical network caused by bushfires across the South East of NSW.

Power is progressively being restored to remaining customers affected however the extent and nature of some damage, coupled with difficulty in safely accessing impacted areas, means some customers will be without power for at least another week, some possibly longer.

While power has been restored to more than 90 percent of those customers affected by bushfire related power outages, crews continue to work to restore power for a further 3300 customers, approximately.

Yesterday, power was restored to 370 customers in areas around Cobargo, Bega and Malua Bay.

Work being carried out today is hoped to restore power to approximately 200 customers in the Bega area, as well as supply power to support water treatment plants in Broyo.

Access for Essential Energy crews to complete electrical network repairs remains challenging with some areas still inaccessible.

In other areas, significant vegetation management scoping is occurring to ensure team safety when working on the network and to remove the likelihood of burnt trees falling on the network once re-energised.

Significant vegetation work is currently taking place throughout the areas around Moruya, Bega and across the Riverina specifically around Tumut, Batlow, Adelong and south to Tumbarumba today, with more than 110 Essential Energy vegetation management team members and contractors on the ground.

Some customers may see power go off and on again as crews work to restore power for all customers.

Updates on power restoration efforts and estimated times for when power will be restored, to customers remaining without supply, will be provided in hard copy to the Emergency Evacuation Centres for distribution.

For further outage information customers can visit the Essential Energy website, www.essentialenergy.com.au or by contacting Essential Energy on 13 20 80

Essential Energy is working to confirm estimated times for when customers will have their power restored, and is communicating with customers directly as this information becomes available.

The following outlines areas where an estimated power restoration time has been provided.

Please note the customer numbers listed below are representative of the areas listed.

Not every location is mentioned as we continue to scope damage to the network.

Essential Energy Bushfire Update - 1.00pm Saturday 11 January 2020

Essential Energy crews worked throughout the weekend to repair damage to the electricity network and progressively restore power to about 3800 customers.

On Friday, Essential Energy crews worked tirelessly to restore power to parts of Malua Bay.

79 crews members worked in Mogo on Saturday to make necessary repairs and restore power to the community and in Jingellic, further damaged was caused to the electricity network, with an additional 20 customers losing power due to active bushfires in the area.

Essential Energy were making repairs and working as quickly as safety allows to try and get power restored.

Essential Energy crews worked in Cobargo, Eden, Bemboka and Nelligen on Saturday.

An additional 64 personnel from across Essential Energy's footprint were arriving in the South Coast and Riverina to provide more on-the-ground support to the 320 Essential Energy personnel who have been working in the region since the bushfire recovery began.

With the migration of the Green Valley, Dunns Road and East Ournie fires in the Snowy Valleys LGA, it is predicted that the electricity network south of Tumbarumba has been impacted by further damage.

Essential Energy was working with the RFS to gain access to the fireground to patrol the network.

For further outage information customers can visit the Essential Energy website, www.essentialenergy.com.au or by contacting Essential Energy on 13 20 80

Essential Energy is working to confirm estimated times for when customers will have their power restored, and is communicating with customers directly as this information becomes available. The following outlines areas where an estimated power restoration time has been provided.

Essential Energy Bushfire Update - 8.00pm, Thursday, January 9 Essential Energy restored power to 760 customers in Surf Beach this evening.

An Essential Energy spokesperson said RMS assisted in the replacement of a power pole located in Talbingo that will enable the Snowy Mountains highway to reopen.

"Our crew leaders have been navigating significant safety issues in numerous locations, resulting from difficult terrain, hazardous trees and active fires. Large machinery including as bulldozers, excavators and elevated working platforms or cherry pickers are being used to assist with restoration efforts," the spokesperson said.

"Getting this large machinery safely into many areas has been and will continue to be, an extremely slow and arduous task."

Weather conditions are predicted to worsen over the coming days in the Riverina and Sapphire Coast.

"Essential Energy crews will continue to undertake restoration work when it is safe to do so and in close consultation with the Rural Fire Service," the spokesperson said.

Essential Energy reminds the community that for safety reasons the electricity network may need to be switched off, or further damage to the network may occur. This means power may not be available for water pumps and customers should have an alternative plan for water if it is required.

Early each morning crews and contractors attend a Toolbox Talk at their 'home depot hub', located at either Tumut, Bega, Albury or Moruya, to address safety, provide condition reports, discuss access challenges, RFS access approvals and weather updates, where vegetation clearing is occurring and to collect their provisions such as lunch and water, for the day.

A State of Emergency was declared in the area of the Goddo's Road fire yesterday by the Rural Fire Service Commissioner.

Public meetings have been held in Nundle and Hanging Rock as a wild bushfire rages and police step up their investigation into what sparked it.

The Goddo's Road fire continues to spread in the Hanging Rock State Forest, and edges closer to the two communities.

Strong winds overnight on Monday led to the fire tripling in size - something that terrified the very people trying to battle it.

"It took a massive run on Monday night," Tamworth Rural Fire Service Inspector Steve Prior told Australian Community Media.

"Everything has been done to try and contain it, but we're trying to stop it at strategic points, to stop it before it gets to the Hanging Rock village and then also going east into Nundle."

The RFS briefed residents at meetings in Nundle and Hanging Rock on Tuesday morning to tell them what was forecast, and what could unfold, if the worst happens.

The fire was almost 1000 hectares in size on Tuesday afternoon and spreading.

"Trying to resource it has been difficult because of how many blazes we have burning across the state at the moment, but the Forestry Corporation is managing the fire because it's a forest fire," Inspector Prior said.

"They have got crews coming from anywhere they can, and we are really getting stretched. But we have had brigades out there doorknocking all the homes in the Hanging Rock area to keep them up to date, so they know what is happening."

Crews were also battling to stop it from taking the timber plantations that have been growing for decades.
